title: How to increase your IQ - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, I can give you some anecdotal evidence. My IQ used to not be measurable. For example, on the GRE, I scored 800 on the Verbal (a perfect score) and 790 on the Math (missed one question.) People aren’t supposed to score that high, and I was head-hunted by universities all over the U.S. I flew out to San Francisco, courtesy UCSF, all expenses paid, for several days. It was a lot like a free vacation. I could have gone just about anywhere I wanted, because just about every U.S. university sent me invitations. I went with Vanderbilt’s offer: total free ride, plus $22K/year. No teaching duties, lots of lab (which I wanted). UCSF has great teachers, but they’re all overloaded on mentoring. They also lack lab and office space. Vanderbilt offered higher quality of life. On IQ tests, I would score 180 and above. In that region, the numbers don’t really mean anything any more. Then I got hit by a truck. (Not my fault.) Now I’m just a “regular” genius, with an IQ of about 150 or so. Still score weirdly high on verbal tests. So, those are some credentials. Why was I a genius? Here’s my best bet: When I was very small—about 2 or 3 years old—my mother taught me to read. It was a wonderful childhood imprinting experience. I was on my mother’s lap, she was paying attention to me in all the good ways, and I was very happy. Every lesson was very enjoyable. I believe any average child could be taught to read early this way. Because of the way I was taught reading, and how early I learned to read, a love of reading was instilled in me. Plus, I soon could read about 1,000 words per minute. When I was 5 years old, I would sit on the kitchen table reading the NY Times. That freaked out my uncle—he still tells that story as if it’s remarkable. All my life I’ve always read far more than the average person. I enjoy it. This may possibly be due to early imprinting, but who cares? So, I know more stuff and have a higher vocabulary than most people. I still always win at games like Trivial Pursuit, even though I never play them on my own. Early enrichment is key, I think. Tiny children are little sponges, wanting to soak up as much information as possible. We know by experimenting with mammals, the more you enrich their early environment (starting from birth) , the smarter AND more able to deal with stress they become. So that’s my answer.

In theory IQ tests measure your speed of learning. You can change this somewhat: In the short term as much as 50% of the difference in IQ between you and another person is environmental and therefore changeable. However, some of this will disappear when you quit doing whatever you did to increase it.In the long term only about 22.5% of the increase remains permanent.Previously I said “A useful thing most people do not think of is to cultivate friends with higher IQ. It will rub off. But only slightly higher, otherwise it will be too difficult to understand their thinking and learn anything from them.” Based on my research, I’d modify that to say you must place yourself in stimulating environments similar to the ones experienced by people with higher IQ. They will probably have higher IQ people in them. There are some issues: You may not spontaneously enjoy these environments, e.g. working puzzles instead of shooting hoops. How badly do you want to increase your IQ?It comes with a cost. Drinking and partying time will have to give way to IQ stimulation. I’m not talking about a small cost either. You know it takes a lot of time in the gym to increase muscle mass. Well, IQ is more difficult by at least 3 or 4 times.You can only absorb efficiently from environments about 20 to 30 IQ points above your own. At 40 points different you won’t understand what is going on.But you can stage it. You can use a first environment to increase your IQ 10 or 15 points, and then move to a higher environment.This means you will be continually outgrowing old friends and needing to make new ones. The number of people who will follow you on your journey is, sadly, zero. You must decide that there are other values in these old friends. But you will not have as much time for them as before, and they will begin to seem parochial and narrow-minded to you, maybe even naive or slow. You will find yourself alienated from all political parties, and unable to participate in committees because they seem intolerably stupid. You will become unable to tolerate your boss or to manage your subordinates effectively. I suggest you become financially independent before embarking on a serious IQ boost.I also suggest you have children first, because IQ is negatively correlated with having children. However, if you do it while your children are young, they will, unlike your friends, come with you. Your spouse may not understand.You will not be able to get a new spouse or girlfriend/boyfriend, so keep the old one. Above 130, there are simply too few people to choose from, most will not share your interests, and the good ones are already taken. It is a whole different world than bouncing around near 100 where you can relate to nearly everyone.Learn to guess other people’s IQ. Just observe the vocabulary they use, what kinds of things they “figure out,” and ask them if they have ever had an IQ test. Most people will tell you their score, or hint at it. If you are asking people with IQs over 120, they will be happy someone noticed and happy to tell you. After a while you will be able to guess. This helps you accumulate the required friends. It is also an exercise in thinking and learning.Read everything about IQ. Study population genetics. Study the debate on environmental vs. genetic influence in IQ. Read research papers instead of news articles. Learn to guess what an article will say by reading the abstract. Learn short cut simple techniques to guess at the solutions to mathematical descriptions of problems, especially statistics, without getting bogged down in lengthy computations and lengthy texts.If you start from 100, and place yourself in a 130 environment, you can expect to capture half the difference in a couple of years, up to about 115. 130 people are leaders in ordinary life, excellent at professions such as lawyer, or doctor, but not necessarily college professors or researchers. If you then remove yourself from that environment, you’ll drop back to about 107. Instead, while you are still a fresh 115, find a 145 environment, which is productive researchers (college professors who do more than teach, or people at your company who are consistently able to get R&D funding and produce results, or old-timers who have done these things in the past, or managed large facilities, but now have time to talk and reminisce, but be careful you don’t get stuck just talking and not doing). Look for a variety of people with different styles and opinions, not just people who agree with you. Some of these people will be hard to get along with and eventually get annoyed with you and break contact one or more times. Be polite, but not obsequious. After about 5 years you should again cut the difference in half, and your IQ will now be about 130. But if you relax, it will drop back to maybe 110 or less. If you really want to do it, start a third phase. Locate people with IQ 160 or more. This will almost certainly have to be on the internet. You will by now have written a few research papers yourself, and maybe you can join ResearchGate. It has a few members with high IQ, maybe 5%, more than random people on the street. However, I cannot fully report on this phase as I have not [yet] been able to get very far. If you succeed, you should have a temporary IQ of about 145. If you can keep at it, you will keep this IQ until you run out of energy and can no longer remain in the environment. But it’s also possible you may find yourself hooked, unable to quit opening back doors to the universe and figuring out how things work. Here is a test. If the things you figure out are different than you imagined previously, then they are not the low-to-medium IQ ideas. If they are different than the groups you have passed through, they are not the ordinary 120–140 ideas. Keep an open mind and always look for new angles. If you stay stuck on one idea for a long time, you have probably relapsed. One thing about IQ is no matter how well you understand something, you’ll wake up tomorrow with a new understanding and the feeling that you were stupid yesterday. Then you know you are on your way. Good luck! The world needs you, even if they don’t know it. P.S. You may also enjoy Robert Shuler's answer to If the IQ of everyone on earth was suddenly raised by 15 points, would there be a substantial effect on the quality of life; alternatively, what would be the effect if all IQs were lowered by 15 points? or Robert Shuler's answer to What does an IQ of 145 mean?

You can’t increase your IQ. It is a specific psychometric quantity which is measured with specific tests, and the theory that goes with it suggests that it is stable throughout a person’s life. You will score roughly the same if you sit the same type of IQ test repeated times (with time gaps so as not to remember the test, and with a new test which is similar but not the same as last time) There are however some temporary psychological factors which may affect the performance in the test during the time of assessment. Simply, if you are stressed, anxious, tired or confused, you may not do well. In other words, it is possible to sit a Mensa exam and score low, even fail, but try a few months later and pass. This variation in score is due to the above. For this reason, when you are about to sit an IQ test like WAIS, it is recommended to sleep well the previous night, and perhaps even take some Rhodiola rosea or a similar relaxing herb/supplement. Some people have also said that they improved their result (failed the Mensa test first, but passed in a latter attempt) by buying IQ puzzle books, such as the ones sold by Mensa and similar publishers, and practiced for a long period of time to understand the approach for solving these puzzles. Example titles (search Amazon): Test Your IQ 400 New Tests to Boost Your BrainpowerThe complete book of intelligence testsIQ MindbendersCambridge Self Scoring IQ TestBrain Flexing IQ TestsThe Big Book of Mind-Bending PuzzlesThe Times book of IQ testsThe Ultimate IQ Test BookMensa Ultimate Mental ChallengeUltimate Psychometric Tests Over 1000 Verbal, Numerical, Diagrammatic and IQ Practice TestsPopular writers of these books include Terry Stickels, Phillip Carter, Ken Russel. Also you will find many titles by Mantesh publishing. Note that IQ testing does not measure the full scale of intelligence. It tends to measure mostly how rational and logical someone is more than anything else. If you want to be more intelligent in another area, this is a different topic. As neuroscience and science overall advances, theories about intelligence are being reconsidered, and even whether one’s IQ can increase is discussed. There is no concrete finding that it is possible. For example, nootropic substances, which did not exist when the theory about IQ was out, exist today, and some of them may improve cognitive performance, resulting in scoring higher on an IQ test. Yet these have not been fully tested on humans officially. If it was easy to become super intelligent, then everyone would be super intelligent. And if anyone knew a secret to how to become super intelligent, they would probably use it for themselves, become extremely successful (which is what you want, isn’t it?), and charge a bucketload of money for petty advice to the super antagonistic Silicon Valley core audience of Quora - not give it away for free, right? Just saying…. Do you think intelligent people are… stupid? Just saying… Do you think I am stupid?… Just saying… Reminds me of that old quote…. “When dealing with people, remember you are not dealing with creatures of logic, but with creatures bristling with prejudice and motivated by pride and vanity.” - Dale Carnegie True… How true! It turns out I’m answering a ton of questions about IQ with the mindset that people want to understand how their mind works in a theoretical sense, and how to measure its abilities, or understand human nature in a scientific way. Utter bullshit! That is how I approached them, it seems. The most appropriate interpretation to most IQ questions apparently is “how can I be better than everyone else, be really rich and successful, and leave my name in history?” On top there is the group of haters who say everyday that people who talk about IQ are losers - requoting Stephen Hawking as a credibly appearing excuse to hide their own vanity - who also think that anyone who talks about IQ equates it with success, and also thinks antagonistically like they do. “You have high IQ? So are you telling me you are better than me?” - “No, I was saying that you are an assh+… oh look, a 100 dollar note!…Sorry, I have to go, I have an appointment with the dentist” Which brings me back to the previous point: You want me to make you super intelligent (so as to become successful, of course)? You gotta pay me for it dude! That’s what I research on…. How is that possible if there is no official scientific answer yet? Well, if you wait for the body of science to agree and publicly announce the answer and make it common knowledge across the world - if that ever happens - wait for 100 years, by the time that it will be a) pointless because everyone will know and b) too late, because well, you’ll be dead. But if you want a solution now… you have to be bold - and fairly rich! Besides…. The last famous person who tried to help people, teach kindness, cure leprosy, make disabled people walk and stick people’s ears back out of good will was crucified.The last famous person who bought into people’s vanity* became the current US president.I’d rather choose the latter fate on this one. Jesus is slowly losing popularity anyway. + assholes: it’s those guys with high IQ, no? * See Trump University

You Can Increase Your Intelligence: 5 Ways to Maximize Your Cognitive Potential! What is "Intelligence"? First of all, let me explain what I mean when I say the word "intelligence". To be clear, I'm not just talking about increasing the volume of facts or bits of knowledge you can accumulate, or what is referred to as crystallized intelligence—this isn't fluency or memorization training—it's almost the opposite, actually. I'm talking about increasing your fluid intelligence, or your capacity to learn new information, retain it, then use that new knowledge as a foundation to solve the next problem, or learn the next new skill, and so on. Any one of these things by itself is great, but if you really want to function at your absolute cognitive best, you should do all five, and as often as possible. In fact, I live my life by these five principles. If you adopt these as fundamental guidelines, I guarantee you will be performing at your peak ability, surpassing even what you believe you are capable of—all without artificial enhancement. Best part: Science supports these principles by way of data! 1. Seek Novelty It is no coincidence that geniuses like Einstein were skilled in multiple areas, or polymaths, as we like to refer to them. Geniuses are constantly seeking out novel activities, learning a new domain. It’s their personality. There is only one trait out of the "Big Five" from the Five Factor Model of personality (Acronym: OCEAN, or Openness, Conscientiousness, Extroversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism) that correlates with IQ, and it is the trait of Openness to new experience. People who rate high on Openness are constantly seeking new information, new activities to engage in, new things to learn—new experiences in general [2]. When you seek novelty, several things are going on. First of all, you are creating new synaptic connections with every new activity you engage in. These connections build on each other, increasing your neural activity, creating more connections to build on other connections—learning is taking place. Take home point: Be an "Einstein". Always look to new activities to engage your mind—expand your cognitive horizons. Learn an instrument. Take an art class. Go to a museum. Read about a new area of science. Be a knowledge junkie. 2. Challenge Yourself There are absolutely oodles of terrible things written and promoted on how to "train your brain" to "get smarter". When I speak of "brain training games", I’m referring to the memorization and fluency-type games, intended to increase your speed of processing, etc, such as Sudoku, that they tell you to do in your "idle time" (complete oxymoron, regarding increasing cognition). I'm going to shatter some of that stuff you've previously heard about brain training games. Here goes: They don't work. Individual brain training games don't make you smarter—they make you more proficient at the brain training games. Now, they do serve a purpose, but it is short-lived. The key to getting something out of those types of cognitive activities sort of relates to the first principle of seeking novelty. Once you master one of those cognitive activities in the brain-training game, you need to move on to the next challenging activity. Figure out how to play Sudoku? Great! Now move along to the next type of challenging game. There is research that supports this logic. 3. Think Creatively When I say thinking creatively will help you achieve neural growth, I am not talking about painting a picture, or doing something artsy, like we discussed in the first principle, Seeking Novelty. When I speak of creative thinking, I am talking about creative cognition itself, and what that means as far as the process going on in your brain. Contrary to popular belief, creative thinking does not equal "thinking with the right side of your brain". It involves recruitment from both halves of your brain, not just the right. Creative cognition involves divergent thinking (a wide range of topics/subjects), making remote associations between ideas, switching back and forth between conventional and unconventional thinking (cognitive flexibility), and generating original, novel ideas that are also appropriate to the activity you are doing. In order to do this well, you need both right and left hemispheres working in conjunction with each other. 4. Do Things the Hard Way I mentioned earlier that efficiency is not your friend if you are trying to increase your intelligence. Unfortunately, many things in life are centered on trying to make everything more efficient. This is so we can do more things, in a shorter amount of time, expending the least amount of physical and mental energy possible. However, this isn’t doing your brain any favors. Take one object of modern convenience, GPS. GPS is an amazing invention. I am one of those people GPS was invented for. My sense of direction is terrible. I get lost all the time. So when GPS came along, I was thanking my lucky stars. But you know what? After using GPS for a short time, I found that my sense of direction was worse. If I failed to have it with me, I was even more lost than before. So when I moved to Boston—the city that horror movies and nightmares about getting lost are modeled after—I stopped using GPS. I won’t lie—it was painful as hell. I had a new job which involved traveling all over the burbs of Boston, and I got lost every single day for at least 4 weeks. I got lost so much, I thought I was going to lose my job due to chronic lateness (I even got written up for it). But—in time, I started learning my way around, due to the sheer amount of practice I was getting at navigation using only my brain and a map. I began to actually get a sense of where things in Boston were, using logic and memory, not GPS. I can still remember how proud I was the day a friend was in town visiting, and I was able to effectively find his hotel downtown with only a name and a location description to go on—not even an address. It was like I had graduated from navigational awareness school. Technology does a lot to make things in life easier, faster, more efficient, but sometimes our cognitive skills can suffer as a result of these shortcuts, and hurt us in the long run. Now, before everyone starts screaming and emailing my transhumanist friends to say that I’ve sinned by trashing tech—that’s not what I’m doing. 5. Network And that brings us to the last element to maximize your cognitive potential: Networking. What’s great about this last objective is that if you are doing the other four things, you are probably already doing this as well. If not, start. Immediately. By networking with other people—either through social media such as Facebook or Twitter, or in face-to-face interactions—you are exposing yourself to the kinds of situations that are going to make objectives 1-4 much easier to achieve. By exposing yourself to new people, ideas, and environments, you are opening yourself up to new opportunities for cognitive growth. Being in the presence of other people who may be outside of your immediate field gives you opportunities to see problems from a new perspective, or offer insight in ways that you had never thought of before. Learning is all about exposing yourself to new things and taking in that information in ways that are meaningful and unique—networking with other people is a great way to make that happen. I’m not even going to get into the social benefits and emotional well-being that is derived from networking as a factor here, but that is just an added perk. Reference: Google I hope you liked it! Here you might have learnt two things. Crystallised intelligence.Fluid intelligence.

This is controversial. Twin studies have found that IQ is about 75% hereditary in adults but there is that 25% and this is a random population so doesn't rule out the possibility of IQ increase. And we know that IQ has been going up around the world -- the Flynn Effect. Some of this likely has to do with lower exposure to toxins like lead and alcohol and better nutrition and health, but some of it probably also has to do with a more enriching environment, particularly during childhood. Brain regions increase in size when exercised for a time, e.g., six months, so it's possible that some IQ increase is possible with the right stimulation. Attempts have been made to create games and so forth to do this with results that are still undetermined. I have also become increasingly sensitive to the fact that INTJ's are unusually smart. I have long suspected that this has to do with a *way* of thinking that both exercise the mind and maximizes what it can do given its biology. These skills are basically a result of figuring things out for oneself from an early age and it's possible that with exercise a younger person or adult could hone those skills in himself. Stimulants improve performance on some measures of mental ability -- caffeine, nicotine, study drugs, and drugs of abuse. Except for the first, all have serious potential for addiction and abuse, though. Study drugs and powerful illegal stimulants can, if used to excess, reduce intellectual performance -- in effect, turning you into a blithering idiot who thinks bugs are crawling under his skin. Study drugs have been called the new nicotine, the modern counterpart to the scholar's pipe. Unfortunately, they are no more healthy. Conversely, marijuana and alcohol are hell on your IQ (though those who drink moderately retain their faculties longer into old age than those who don't-- and live longer as well). Finally, I wouldn't overlook the value of serious reading and great art. They exercise your brain and provide the background and understanding without which IQ is useless. I'd swear that after I've listened to Bach, my IQ goes up 20 points. And when I lived in California, it went 20 points in the opposite direction, LOL.

If you mean increasing real intelligence (organically), not just obtaining a higher Mensa score, it’s not an easy feat; not impossible, just not easy. You have to deal with three main problems. #1 - The solidified hardware of your brain, which is most likely becoming wired for life. #2 - Genetics. You’re born with X amount of ability, which diminishes over time. #3 - Input. I’ll assume you’re an American, which…the American lifestyle—work and our superficial society—are not conducive to raising intelligence. I did say, it’s not impossible. If a person really wanted to raise their intelligence, they would have to deal with their hardwired brain. Vigorous exercise, nootropics, and bombardment of new information would be a good start. There are simple things you can do, like changing routes to work, using your non-dominant hand, and doing things in the dark. This is to “upset” the brain’s hardwiring, thus forcing your neurons to make new connections. New connections can lead to greater intelligence. With genetics, there is gene therapy and growth hormones, but a less invasive approach, would once again, be nootropics, exercise, change in diet, etc. There is a mountain of research that supports meditating your way to greater intelligence. Basically, a person would need to flip overall good health into overdrive. Neurogenesis isn’t impossible, but it does require a lot of effort. Now comes the information. To really raise one’s intelligence, a person needs diverse input, and lots of stimulation; our society isn’t exactly great for this. But, never fear, basically everything you have been doing up to now, stop. Turn off the TV (no, not even the ‘good’ shows are that great), reduce online social time, trade that time with hands on hobbies, outside social events, and reading books. The number one way to provide stimulating input, and gain intelligence points, is to begin an adventure into eclectic reading. The importance of reading books cannot be overstated. There are other methods, like hanging around smarter people, and listening to how they come to solutions, and of course going back to school (free online courses are also great). There is no shame in learning from and emulating more intelligent people. Break out of your routines. Most people don’t bother raising intelligence, because our society doesn’t really reward intelligence. I commend anyone wanting to be better, whether it’s athletically, academically, or professionally. Good luck in your endeavors.

The easiest change that is likely to improve cognitive performance is in the area of diet. In particular, a proper ratio of omega 3 to omega 6 fatty acids in the diet is needed for proper cortical brain function. While these benefits have been proven in clinical trials only in young children - incidentally likely accounting for part of the 7 IQ point advantage of breastfeeding, which has also been proven - they likely apply to adults as well. The ideal ratio of omega 3s to omega 6s is about 1:1 or 1:2. These days, most people get most of their dietary fat from vegetable oils which have an unbalanced ratio in the range of 1:20 or 1:30. Getting rid of the vegetable oils in favor of animal fat from pastured animals is ideal. Failing that, getting some omega 3s from fatty fish, the best source, can partially offset the poor fatty acid balance of vegetable oils. For people older than the onset of metabolic syndrome, typically in the 40s, excessive blood sugar levels and swings tends to become an issue. A reduction in dietary carbohydrate intake - less sugar and starch - can help avoid this issue. There may be some additional benefit to going to a ketogenic diet, which provides an alternative source of energy to the brain - ketones instead of glucose - especially as ketones provide more usable energy per unit of oxygen. The next easiest change is exercise. For older adults - again, roughly those of us past the onset of metabolic syndrome - exercise is useful, probably because it helps burn off excessive blood sugar levels and stores. Anaerobic exercise is especially effective since it burns blood sugar less efficiently, and thus uses more of it. Then, there are changes in intellectual habits. In particular, it’s likely worthwhile to do a lot of reading. This is partly because reading builds vocabulary, which contributes to most peoples’ definition of intelligence and also is an element in many IQ tests. In addition, though, critical reading - thinking about what is read and its implications - helps one practice logical and rational analysis. Don’t worry about reading things that you think are good for you; just read what you enjoy enough to think about analytically. Find quiet, undisturbed time to do your reading. Learning math through calculus is probably also useful. Math at these levels - arithmetic through algebra to calculus - is applicable to all sorts of everyday issues. Do you have enough money to make it through payday? Arithmetic. What combination of potluck dishes do you need to make sure everyone has enough main course and dessert at that party? Algebra. Can you make it through the yellow light before it turns red? Calculus. I’m not saying you should break out the pencil and paper and write down equations for all these things, but if you’ve fully learned the math, you should be able to apply the concepts to these and many other everyday problems, even if your goal is not an exact numerical answer. Edit: Finally, there are other people. The more time you spend in the company of people smarter than you are - but not so much smarter you can’t understand them - the more opportunity you have to learn things from them, including thinking habits. Perhaps this one should have been first. Don’t expect an overnight change. Even babies take years to demonstrate the benefits from that initial year of breastfeeding. Keep up the good habits year after year, though, and you’ll likely see some benefits.

Increase your actual IQ? Sorry,but if you’re old enough to be posting on Quora, you’re pretty much stuck with that number. During pregnancy, proper nutrition helps. Having the mother stay *completely* off alcohol, tobacco, and drugs helps a lot. A stimulating environment the first few years of life helps. Increase your effective intelligence? There’s *plenty* you can do to help there, no matter what your age. Even if you’re a senior citizen, do this stuff - it will help prevent depression and senility (seriously - there’s tons of research on this). If nothing else, it will keep you busy in retirement. Somebody with an IQ of 120 who’s educated and informed will have a far higher effective intelligence than somebody who’s got an IQ of 140 but is uninformed and ignorant (sadly - such ignorance is usually totally intentional and self-inflicted). So how do you do it? Read. Learn things - doesn’t even matter what. A new language, chess, a musical instrument, calculus. Learn what critical thinking is. This seems to be a vanishing skill, at least in the US. What is it? Basically, it’s making sure you have a functioning bullshit detector, and it’s a valuable skill indeed, especially if you live in a country with free elections. When you read a news story, think about whether the person/company reporting the news to you has an agenda or bias. Then, equally important, think about whether the person who gave them the info has an agenda or bias. Do fact-checking - and use fact checkers that are outside your comfort zone rather than ones that just tell you what you want to hear. As a worked example - consider the US President’s press secretary giving a press briefing. Listen to the *full* briefing. Take a quote from the press secretary and fact check it. Did they tell us something that’s verifiably true, or does it sound implausible? Go listen to the Fox and MSNBC coverage of the briefing it’s guaranteed those two won’t report it the same way. What do they say about it? Do they quote accurately, or do they use partial quotes, or take them out of context? Learn to follow the money. Did I mention reading?

Legally, IQ can only really go to ~210–250. I don’t know if the mathematical limit is 250, but I know 210 is the highest recorded IQ as of now. Now, when we deconstruct IQ and start to look at it from a more conceptual understanding, it becomes a much more complex answer. On one end, IQ can theoretically go to infinity given the human is able to increase brain size while maintaining overall connectivity and preserving all brain portions in terms of their relative percentages. This type of human within a range 10000+ would be (and I am playing a bit of a science fiction hypothetical scenario here since nobody really knows): Able to process and remember millions of data points simultaneously and unconsciouslyProbably would be able to envelop multiple points of consciousness (meaning that their overall conscious could envelop multiple separate completely focused consciouses.)Most likely be able to visualize complex hyperspheres and communicate the data to those below themBe able to create near perfect fits of complex topographical structuresBe able to simulate future trends in the world due to their ability to handle complex sums wellMost likely due to total command of every life form below itself, the human would start to believe he/she was a literal godWould be able to visualize the world mentally just by identifying simple trends and fundamental rules, and be able to simulate it just as well as humans can the real worldWould most likely early on try to control their emotions successfully using drugs, injections, or cognitive techniquesA human with this kind of intelligence would most likely seek nothing from humans given they would be far behind this human’s abilities before the human even became an adult. Generally, IQ needs to be changed in definition as we increase the bounds as long as the initial mean, SDs, and effects of increases or decreases in SD are kept the same.

When I went through school I realized that you need to learn how to study. They should teach a course on how to study alone! It's a science it really is and if you don't know how to study you're fucked. For lack of a better term. Study takes a certain amount of discipline which I suck at. So I developed study habits that were probably the least burdensome and most efficient to get the job done ( high or passing grades) It depends too on your education. Are you in high school? Then you need higher grades. Are you in college ? Then you only need passing grades unless you're in a graduate program that demands a minimum GPA. I think it's different for everyone. Probably the best thing for you is to talk to people that can show you and teach you in person. But for me it was basically studying my professors and really learning what key words they would use when something was going to be on a test, half of it really is learning how to take good notes. Some professors don't use the text book at all. Most. Some only use the text. You have to really learn how to listen. Listening is half the battle. The professor will tell you how to get an A. It's up to you to believe them and listen for it. To hear it. Every professor I had , would have key words or certain language they would use to indicate that this was important. Write good notes on that stuff. For me too , I think maintaining an almost objective view , like the eagle compared to the mouse. It's easy to get overwhelmed in school and you don't have to. I think they purposely try to confuse and overwhelm you, and if you can rise above that or see through that, it's easy. For example they make a question sound really complicated to hide its simplicity. For example we think we need to memorize things exactly as they are defined in the text book. These long, pedantic definitions that people really try to memorize. Don't. Learn what the word means in your own language in your own head and you'll be able to pick it out just fine or define it. A lot of school is unnessary bullshit like that. Meant to purposely intimidate people and confuse them. It's very tempting in school to overwhelm yourself. Study what you need to know for the tests. That in itself makes things much easier. Use memory tricks. Word associations and the like. Try to step back and understand things on a simplistic level. On a very simple level. Write things out in the simplest equation or least complicated formula or theory. Step back and memorize that. It's still essentially the exact same thing just without all the bullshit they add on. What I would do is when I got home I would go through my notes. I would make myself a test with those notes. All of them from the day. I would go through it and do it till I had every question answered correctly and memorized about three times. The first time I would go through it I would mark the ones I got wrong. Next time just the questions I got wrong and the third time the questions I still got wrong till I answered every one correctly and then I would take the test another time and do the process all over till I missed none. About three times. Usually. For really hard courses like pharmacology, or anatomy, I used flash cards but the best way for me personally was these tests. Sometimes for harder courses it helped to have someone else read me my questions. But to condense my answer - listening is key. Learn how to listen to people. Professors will tell you what will be on the test with subtle ques and hints and key words they will use. Usually the subjects that they spend any amount of time on will be on the test. Second most important thing- note taking. Take great notes. If you're not good at notes bring a tape recorder and always sit in the front row in class. This really helps. It does. Third most important thing- simplify. They really try to complicate the simplest concepts. If you can learn to peel away the bullshit or big words and get down to the heart of the formula or concept it's so much easier. Fourth most important thing- don't doubt yourself. Whether you memorize the word nucleon with the text definition or your own, you will still comprehend it. Which is the point. You won't miss the answer no matter what.

You can’t really increase your IQ in any measurable way. IQ Tests don’t measure knowledge. I think there’s a misconception about what IQ is. It’s not a measure of any sort of achievement. It’s a measure of a physical property of the brain. It’d be like asking, “what can I do to be taller?” By the time you can ask that question, most of the opportunity to get taller has already passed, but if you want to help your children be taller, you might be able to with good nutrition. I mean, maybe you could wear platform shoes to appear taller. Stand up straight, shoulders back. It doesn’t really make you taller, but it might seem that way. It’d be like taking cognitive enhancement drugs before you take the test. The score might be higher, but for what? Why do you even care what your IQ is? It’s not a competition of scores. Do you need a particular score to do something? Probably not. IQ is just a measure of something about us that we can’t control. Like shoe size. Who cares how big your shoes are? What can you do? If anything? Eat healthy foods containing brain boosters like Omega 3 fatty acids. Learn constantly. It might not make you more intelligent, but it’ll put your intelligence to use. You’ll gain knowledge you can apply to the world around you. You won’t be more intelligent and thus you won’t get a higher IQ, but you’ll be better equipped to manipulate your environment with experience. It would be easier to protect your current intelligence from declining by protecting your brain. Don’t play head concussing sports like football or boxing. Don’t do drugs or drink too much. Don’t hang out with emotionally abusive people. They might not make you less intelligent, but they’ll sap your motivation and inhibit your achievements. You can’t change the number of colors in the box, but you can do more with the colors you’ve got. You can learn how to mix colors to make new ones. You can create amazing works of art. Or you can just leave them in the box. There’s a big difference. It’s not what you have, it’s what you do with it.

From an early age (like age 0-5) during the critical time-periods when the brain is developing and growing you can increase IQ by simply eating enough food (calories) and getting certain nutrition (iodine). The brain won't develop properly without enough food and certain nutrition. Also perhaps anytime until age 14-19 or so diet might have a big effect on IQ. Humans reach 80% of their adult brain size by age 2, 90% by age 5, and 100% by age 14-19. Iodine seems to have a big effect on IQ (The Effects of Iodine Deficiency in Pregnancy and Infancy, Iodine deficiency as a cause of brain damage, Intelligence Quotient and Iodine Intake: A Cross-Sectional Study in Children). Multiple studies show that iodine boosts IQ by 10-15 points or so (during early ages)…but I don’t know if it will have any effect after the brain has stopped developing. Seaweed and iodized salt are high in iodine content. Now after the brain has stopped developing and growing much (around age 14-19) there's probably not much you can do except: Temporary starvation has been shown to elevate stem cells in the body, including in the brain which causes neurogenesis (the generation of the new neurons) A periodic diet that mimics fasting promotes multi-system regeneration, enhanced cognitive performance and healthspanCertain mind-exercises allegedly increase IQ (but I’m not sure if any studies have been done on it).There’s one exercise that allegedly allows you to have an extremely high IQ if you practice it enough (like IQ 150+), it’s called image streaming.What you do is for 10–30 minutes a day close your eyes and describe aloud any subject in as much sensory detail as possible. It could be any subject or topic like, say “the beach”. With your eyes shut you would describe the sight, sound, feeling, taste, smell of the beach, the sand, the sky, etc…in as much detail as possible out loud while imagining the sensory details.I tried this exercise once or twice but not consistently (since I was never really interested in increasing IQ) but I noticed that imagining and visualizing things became much easier so becoming good at image streaming really may increase your IQ dramatically. You would be able to visualize and imagine things easily if you became good at it.I wonder what would happen if kids practiced this at early ages….I wonder if any experiments or studies have been done on the effects on this exercise. What if we could easily make any population have IQs 150+?Nikola Tesla wrote in his autobiography about how he use to see images in his mind and practiced imagining things at a young age (something very similar to image streaming):“Every night (and sometimes during the day), when alone, I would start on my journeys—see new places, cities and countries—live there, meet people and make friendships and acquaintances and, however unbelievable, it is a fact that they were just as dear to me as those in actual life and not a bit less intense in their manifestations. This I did constantly until I was about seventeen when my thoughts turned seriously to invention. Then I observed to my delight that I could visualize with the greatest facility. I needed no models, drawings or experiments. I could picture them all as real in my mind. “ (Tesla, Nikola. My inventions. the Philovox, 1919.)My personal guess is that if little kids practiced this image streaming exercise daily until a certain age they would probably grow up to have a super-high IQ, but I’m not sure it would really have the same effect on adults (since their brain stopped developing and is physically deteriorating).It could be that increasing your IQ is similar to increasing muscle mass (nutrition and certain exercises) or it could be fixed and nearly unchangeable after a certain age…who knows.

Ron Richards’ answer focuses on whether you’re trying to get a good score on a test—for what reason I dunno. Benjamin Sun’s answer focuses on the process level. To their entries let me add a few bits. First, those of us born with high IQs may not be the best help for you, because your best model is people who made themselves smarter by dint of hard work, while for the rest of us it came naturally without conscious effort. That said, I’ve noticed that people with lower IQs tend to want easy answers; to want certainty at the expense of reality; have lower tolerance for ambiguity; and lack autocognition—self-awareness. For example, when I see a political campaign ad for a candidate/issue/party I favor, I will usually feel a strong desire to agree enthusiastically. Agreement feels good. Feeling self-righteous feels good. But i fight it, even though I feel a kind of “wind” blowing at my back. Because I’m far more committed to knowing the truth than to just feel good. And I’m painfully aware of the many, many times I’ve used my high IQ to rationalize believing and/or doing stupid things. It’s autocognition that saves you from that kind of folly. This kind of self-reflection, the ability to watch yourself doing something, so to speak, that distinguishes smarties from dummies. Then there’s curiosity. The not so smart often don’t want to learn something unless they know how it can benefit them up front (if it isn’t the sort of scandal/outrage/spicy stuff that fills the pages of tabloids). I don’t know if you can learn curiosity, but if you aren’t naturally curious maybe you can train yourself to explore more, just as someone on the austistic spectrum who’s face blind can teach himself to “read” faces—something that comes naturally to the rest of us. The essence of intelligence is disciplined playfulness. I read a book on string theory, every though that’s way outside my areas of expertise. And it was hard slogging. But I didn’t do it to make money at something or to get a higher score on a test—I did it because I wanted to have a better idea of how things work, whether I could monetize that at some point or not. Intelligent people also tend to exhibit a lot of laterality—seeing relationships others miss. Xerox Corporation developed the first graphical user interface, but Steve Jobs was the one who “got” how it could revolutionize computer use. And they’re also good at filtering out fake connections, which social media are full of (conspiracy theorizing). Now consider this critter:  You’ve probably never seen or heard of it before. If you’re highly intelligent you’ll find out what it is, even though knowing that will probably never make you a cent or enable you to impress anyone who isn’t a biologist. Ready, set, go!

Before I talk about how to boost intelligence we first have to define the term (but, if you want to go to the best way to boost your intelligence simply scroll down and skip the next 2 parts):  Intelligence is a very fickle term. Most of us think of IQ (Intelligence Quotient) when talking about it, assuming that it shows how smart you are. Therefore, increasing your IQ, or your intelligence, should make you smarter, more versatile in how you use your brain, generally a better student and more adapt to handle difficult situations. But this is not at all what intelligence is. Your IQ is merely a number used to predict how well you will do in school. Nothing more. It doesn’t mean you are smart, dumb, versatile or can handle difficult situations at all. It just means that if you have a higher number you are going to be more adapt to handling the school system.  That being said, if you want to boost your intelligence it depends on what intelligence you want to boost:  These are 9 types of intelligence taken from 9 Types Of Intelligence - Infographic. Here you can clearly see that just having an higher IQ does not determine how smart you are in the world. There are too many things for us to learn and some of us are going to be more intelligent in certain areas than others. Just because the logical-mathematical intelligence is most often used in schools does not mean it is the only type.  That being said, the single best way to increase your intelligence (in any of these intelligences) is to challenge yourself. When you go outside your comfort zone and challenge yourself you obtain experiences that will push you to handle the situation for whatever it is. No matter how much you think about something, unless you experience it you will never know how to handle it. But once you have experienced it you will be able to use that knowledge in every other area of your life. Think about this question: How come most masters in any field seem so smart in other fields? It’s because they can transfer what they learned in their field onto any other area of life. For example, let’s take a martial artist and ask them about how the universe works. If they understand it even slightly they will make analogies with martial arts to explain it better to themselves, because that is where they have the most amount of knowledge and wisdom. They have experienced more in this one field by forcing themselves into countless uncomfortable situations and grew in their intelligence. Of course the martial artist master may not be a master in seeing how nature works and will not have the greenest of thumbs, but they will be able to pick it up more quickly than most because of their ability to transfer their knowledge. That is why the wise are always very old; they just have experienced the most! This has changed with the times, especially since the world the younger generations live is vastly different than the one the older generations lived in, but in older times this was certainly true. Experiencing life, overcoming challenges and solving problems hands on is the best way to boost your intelligence. If you have to fight for survival every day you will be extremely intelligent in survival within no time. If you force yourself to talk to 30 strangers every day, your social intelligence will be astronomical within just a few months. The first question you should ask yourself is in what area you want to become more intelligent in. The second question is: What is the most challenging thing you can do in this field? And then go out and do it!

An IQ of 100 is average. IQ is not like an exam where 100 is the highest score. 100 means that you have the same intelligence as most people who are the same age as you. An IQ greater than 100 means that you’re intellectual level is above your own age level. Why would you want to be average unless you are well below average? But regardless, what you need to know is that (1) IQ is just a test, and (2) IQ is not fixed. An IQ is just a score given a test much like a test for any other subject matter, and just like any kind of test, one can get better grades if one prepares for the test. If you know the type of test in advance then there are specific techniques that one can learn to improve one’s score during the test, and also learning patterns for the types of questions being asked. As such, having a high IQ in this case simply means that you good at taking that sort of a test. But having a high score is superficial, what you really want is to improve your general intelligence. If what you are really after is becoming truly intelligent, then that can be rectified too, and I don’t mean intelligent in the sense of being educated or simply knowing a lot of facts and trivia. Intelligence is a product of genetics, upbringing, peers/environment and techniques. Nothing much can be done about genetics, and upbringing is a thing of the past if you are already an independent adult. But if you have a normal brain then much can be done to improve it to gain higher intelligence. On the other hand, one has control over both peers and environment. Your choice of the people around you will greatly influence your IQ. It is unavoidable that your peers will rub off on you by your interaction with them. A stimulating and varied environment is also conducive to increasing your general intelligence. There is a well known anecdote about Socrates (real or fictitious) dunking a student under water, click here for the complete story. The main lesson being that one can gain wisdom if one really wanted it. That is why becoming more intelligent is a deliberate choice, there are specific things that you can do and learn to become more intelligent. Technique is actually just a skill to be learned. Intelligent people have the same brain capacity as everyone else but they have learned or discovered more effective thinking techniques. Techniques such as processes, tricks and mental tools that allow you to take shortcuts, think faster or get better results. There are books which teach mental techniques such as the book, “How to be Twice as Smart”, which is highly recommend. “Confident Decision Maker” shows you a more systematic approach to making decisions as opposed to the haphazard approach that most people take. “Thinking Strategically” may be on the higher level but there are many valuable techniques there as well. These and innumerable books like these teach you the techniques that you can use to make more effective use of your brain. But of course, reading them is not enough, the techniques learned need to be practiced and put into practice until they become second nature that one no longer needs to think about them to be of benefit. Techniques can also be discovered by solving puzzles. Many puzzles actually belong to a class of puzzles wherein there are patterns to the solution that can be applied to other similar puzzles. Books by Martin Gardner are a good start. A side benefit of improving one’s intelligence organically is that one will naturally fare better and score higher in IQ tests.

Read.  Everything you can.  Fiction, non-fiction, newpapers, magazines, Quora, online, offline, everything.  If there's "highbrow" stuff that you are particularly interested in, focus on that.  It's easy to find; if you can find a bookstore near you, check out their magazine rack, for starters.  Look online for periodicals like "The Paris Review", "Atlantic Monthly", "Harpers", "National Review"; literature anthologies like "Granta"; and even things like "People", or "Hello" or "OK", magazines like "WWD" ("Womens Wear Daily") and "Architectural Digest" for a sense of applied art, design, and style and popular trends.  Read fiction - good, classic, amazing fiction (Hemingway, Porter, Twain, Harper Lee); sci-fi (LeGuin, Vonnegut, Tolkien, Orwell, Bradbury, Asimov), classic horror (Edgar Allen Poe, Lovecraft, Stoker, Shelley, et. al); non-fiction (Capote, Krakauer, Larson, Lewis) and even book reviews (like the New York Times Book Review section) to see what people are writing about, and what good writers and thinkers think about what they've read.  Check out the best-sellers list, and read.  A lot.  Find something you love; read a few things you might not think you'd like, on recommendation of others, and figure out why you didn't (or why you actually did) end up liking it.  Maybe even join or start a book club, and invite your "more intelligent" friends to be a part of it.   I had a friend in college who was terribly insecure about her intelligence and knowledge.  It was ridiculous; she was a bright, savvy person.  But she felt her "highbrow" knowledge was lacking.  So she reads.  Everything.  And she has far surpassed her so-called "highbrow" and cultured friends, because she has developed an understanding and curiosity about the world that is astonishing, now, in its complexity and breadth.   There's still lots of stuff she doesn't know, but who knows much of anything, really?  Reading is a kickstart to opening up your imagination and recognizing that there are many ways to see the world. Then you might understand where your friends are coming from, how to contrast their perspective with yours, and have some discussions about what you both learn, know and think about.  Chances are they'll start thinking you're the one who has the highbrow. ;-)

The original IQ test was designed in 1904 simply to help to distinguish children who were mentally challenged from children who could do the work, but were simply lazy and entitled. When working with children and you encounter problems, the first thing to ask is if they are doing that because they CANNOT do the task or because they WILL NOT do the task. The IQ test is one way to see, but not the only way. The IQ test only tests how quickly we can process and use information. It does not test your strengths socially, emotionally, or anything except intelligence. To say that one’s IQ determines the value of a person is just plain wrong. There is so much more that makes up who you are, and ALL of it is important. If your IQ test measures 99, then it shows that you are right in with everyone else, right at the top of the bell curve.  It means you have lots of company! If you look at the curve, while anything is possible, the IQ numbers are not even listed below 55 and above 145. Personally, I think that your friend (and others) are not being honest, and certainly inflated with his or her own view of themselves. You cannot increase your IQ up to 200. So what? To do that would be like me trying to be six foot tall. No matter how hard I’d try, I’d never grow an inch. In fact, in my seventies, I keep getting shorter every year! But the question is this: what can we do to improve ourselves? Are we becoming more mature every year? Do we have an attitude of love and kindness? Do we push back against injustice and help those around us? Remember, you are uniquely qualified to accomplish some things on this earth that no one else will do as well as you will. Some of those things will be noticed by the rest of the world, and many of them will be done in anonymity, but the truth is that it is all important. The choice is up to you, to be all you are created to be, or to focus on what you cannot control. It sounds like your friend has a bit of growing up to do!

About improving cognitive function through training, specific training can only improve specific cognitive functions, such as your Japanese Listening Practice can not improve your ability to read Japanese Characters, let alone can not help you learn to draw Manga. It depends on what cognitive functions you need to improve. For example, practicing to memorize some words and retelling them after a while, practicing to memorize a number string and then retell it, can improve your technique of remembering complex texts that have no special meaning. Moving target shooting game can improve the ability to handle complex visual information. Practice mental arithmetic can improve your ability to counting in everyday life, but can not improve your higher mathematics test scores. The best cognitive training is to do your favorite job or have a fun hobby and try to do it best. In this way, you train the cognitive functions you need most and do not waste extra time. For example, learning a new language, learning to draw comics and manga, can improve your multiple cognitive functions. Playing computer games may improve certain cognitive functions, but in order to prevent you from indulging in them, it is not recommended to play too much. Shooting exercises and automobile racing, which are dangerous for yourself and others, must also be done in a dedicated venue.  About preventing cognitive impairment. First of all, we need to maintain good nutritional intake. For example, people who consume too much monosaccharides and too much fat need to adjust their diet to avoid cardiovascular and cerebrovascular injuries. Vegans need to pay attention to vitamin B12, iron and protein supplements. Second, to maintain a proper length of sleep, you can refer to the recommended sleep time for different ages, when lack of sleep need appropriate supplements. Finally, severe depression and anxiety can impair cognitive function. It is not easy to maintain a good mood. The pressure from the outside world and your own genetic factors are beyond your control. What you could do is believe in a transcendental power (For example, G-d). And when you feel depressed, or feel unwell and lost your interest, you should seek help from doctor as soon as possible. Unfortunately, there are currently no proven methods to prevent a variety of neurodegenerative diseases. What we could do is to prevent cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases through good habits and reduce the damage caused by mood disorders through timely medical treatment.

I just came up with a possible answer to this, in response to a related question: My IQ is 133. Can I become a genius? So I’ll just quote that in it’s entirety. “ Maybe. How hard do you want to try? Are you willing to follow the nebulous advice of some random guy on the internet who everyone thinks is crazy? Because if so, then today’s your lucky day! I have no idea if this will work or not, but you’re free to try, and I’m pretty sure this is the best chance you have. Practice awareness meditation until you can hear your thoughts. If you do it right, this should take a few years. Step 1: practice being aware of something in front of you. Step 2: practice moving your awareness around between multiple things, staying on each thing for a short time. Step 3: practice expanding your awareness, radially, from a single thing; and practice compressing your awareness down to a single point, a sub-portion of a single thing. Step 4: practice moving your awareness into yourself. Step 5: practice becoming aware of a slice of your body, and slowly move that slice through your body, making sure you never lose awareness of the slice. Step 6: practice becoming aware of your whole body all at once. Step 7: practice becoming aware of your base feelings: agitation, annoyance, comfort, etc. If you panic, try to be aware of your panic. If you get in a fighting mood, try to be aware of that. Step 8: practice becoming aware of your general emotions: happiness, fear, sorrow, love, etc. Practice becoming aware of your feelings in response to everything that happens during the day. Step 9: practice becoming aware of your thoughts. Do normal meditation, where you sit down and try to not think, except instead of trying to not think, you’re trying to hear your thoughts. Let your brain think, and follow each thought thoroughly. If you do this right, you’ll notice your wandering thoughts come to an end. Okay, at this point, if you’ve done it right, you’ll be able to have a small amount of control of your thoughts, which should make it possible for you to become smarter. Step 10: practice becoming aware of your subconscious. This is a lot harder to explain, and by this time you should be used to it, so just try and see what happens. Step 11: practice taking a singular thought, and expanding the thought itself into a range of thoughts, or a possibility space of thoughts. Also practice taking a singular thought, and compressing it down to a singular sub-thought. Step 12: practice taking two thoughts, expanding them, and mixing the expanded thoughts together. This should allow your brain to perform indirect calculations on fuzzy concepts. Step 13: practice doing step 12 with everyday things, throughout the entire day. Try having a single thought, like driving, held in the back of your mind throughout the entire day, and let it mix with other thoughts, and observe the results. Also try mixing completely unrelated thoughts whenever something new or weird come up. IF you’ve spent the probably 5–10 years it takes to get this far, and IF it even works, then you might very well successfully increase your IQ to just over 150 this way. This is basically how geniuses think, and it might be possible to train your brain to think in the same way. Step 14–16: chain expanded thoughts together to make thought ranges and thought sets. Take two thought sets, and let them mingle. This is 170 IQ. Step 17–19: chain thought ranges and thought sets together until you get the entirety of available possibility space in relation to something working together in your brain. Take two possibility spaces, and let them mingle. Find the local maximums and minimums of the two. This is 190 IQ. I’ve never tried coming up with an actual answer to this before, so this is the first time I’ve genuinely, consciously thought about this (it’s been in the back of my subconscious for a long time, though). Anyway, good luck. This might very well work, or it might not. I’ve done all of this myself, but I had the IQ that makes it easy to begin with. “ If your IQ is 110–130, an additional 3 steps step might be necessary before step 11 where you try to take your thoughts and mix them together to form chains of thoughts without first trying to expand your thoughts. If your IQ is 90–110, an additional 3 steps step might be necessary before the step above where you try to take individual thoughts and mix them together. You may need to pay more attention to your subconscious in order to get results from mixing thoughts. If your IQ is below 90, I don’t know what the additional steps might be. Such additional steps might actually be a part of steps 7–10.

There are many kinds of intelligence: linguistic / verbal, mathematical, spatial, kinetic, musical and so on. Most IQ tests measure a single kind of intelligence - math, verbal, spatial etc. I take your question to mean how can an adult become more intelligent holistically than to improve their score on the dimension tested specifically by an IQ test.    While I do not know if all intelligences (e.g., musical) can be increased even with effort - I suspect not - there are ways to increase "practical intelligence" i.e, have a wide spectrum of knowledge coupled with an ability to see the big-picture by synthesizing first principles from various subjects. Here are some things one can do to increase practical intelligence: 1. Take 101 / 201 courses in world history, philosophy, physics, chemistry, biology, geography, economics, psychology, corporate finance, marketing, analytical methods, art & theater. 2. Read from diverse sources but learn to differentiate opinion from fact; read one random wikipedia article everyday. 3. Observe, question, discuss: A curious mind is likely to be more intelligent. When you read something, think what are the underlying assumptions that must be true for it to hold. What, if proven false, would break the fact / opinion's validity. Observe whether the theories you read can be corroborated with enough (even if anecdotal) evidence. Discuss with those who are equally / better read and curious. 4. Get involved in mini-projects: What you read, you may forget but what you do, you are likely to remember. Get involved in small projects that aren't in the center of your expertise but related at the periphery. For e.g., if you are a marketing professional, see whether there is a project in sales or after-sales service that you can be involved in. These projects could be at work or outside (whether as a volunteer or on a pro-bono or part-time basis). You'll bring in a different perspective while also learning from the views of others who have had different life experiences. 5. Write a Nostradamus Journal: Every week or two, synthesize all your reading / learning into a few trends / predictions along with an expected timeline. Review your previous entries to see whether trends / predictions panned out as you expected and if not, what factors resulted in the change. Think whether those factors were foreseeable or not. Over time, with this exercise, you should become better at seeing the "big picture".

I believe this: you are born with a genetic maximum IQ that you can ever attain. This I would call your Maximum IQ Potential, and it has to do only with your genes. However, very few people reach that maximum potential, unless their upbringing ( nutrition, education, stressors, poverty, health, domestic violence, country of origin, etc) are just right. Therefore, someone may have a measured IQ of, say, 98. Genetically speaking, that individuals’ maximum possible IQ is, say, 118. If conditions are right, and this person works on developing their intellect, then they may achieve an IQ of 115, 117, or up to 118; never higher. Does race play a part in this genetic scenario? Most likely. Ask yourselves: Does race play a part in an individual’s athletic performance? physical Stamina? Physical strength? Probability of a given disease or organ failure? Yes, it does, and science knows it. So, as muscles, livers, blood and glands are organs, and their performance can vary according to a person’s race, so is the brain, which, ultimately is just another organ. The issue is, of course, how to define “race”. If you study dogs, and muddle the difference between races of dogs and breeds of dogs, you will see that all comparisons between breeds are valid and the results are supported by data. The thing is that there is no discrimination when discussing dogs, but we all know which breed of dog is smarter, which one is fiercer and more protective, which have better scent detecting , hunters, herding, which may suffer from a given illness, etc. Same with pure breeds of all domestic animals, chickens, cows, horses, and cats. I have a siamese cat, Clawy, and the predicted traits of her personality and demeanor per her breed, are spot on. She is the only cat I have had who “fetches” like a dog would. Well, I just read that Siamese cats are known to do that! If you met me, you’d see there is not a less racist person in the world. If studies and publications such as “The Bell Curve” are considered to be prejudiced, racists, and based on poorly made tests, the answer is not simply to discount the theory, but to come up with better tests, like tests that better compensate for social environments and cultural differences, and better publications that don’t have underlying agendas. If any serious study is to be undertaken on the subject, the two main components of the study need to be clarified, established and identified. Those are: What is RACE? And What is INTELLIGENCE?, because, believe it or not, concepts as basic and fundamental as those are not clearly defined. Personally, I believe that this index called IQ, as a measure of brain horsepower is a very poor indicator of success. I happen to have been tested with an IQ that is supposed to be high (135), and I can tell you this: To succeed in life I would gladly trade some of that for perseverance, application and will-power to succeed.
