The easiest and quickest way to get smarter is to READ.  The Benefits of READING: Develop your cognition through deep contemplative thinkingExpose yourself to new ideas and conceptsCome up with your own new ideas and theoriesGet information about how the world worksReceive the knowledge and wisdom of successful peopleIncrease your creativity and imaginationMake yourself more intelligent by getting the gist of more ideasLearn from the mistakes of others peopleForce your brain to adapt to the mental stress of having to learn (Neuroplasticity)Expand your horizons and gain competence in a wider range of topicsPut all of that what you’ve learned into action and improve the quality of your life How to Get More Reading into Your Day Make room for daily reading. You have to commit to reading something every single day. The best way is to simply schedule it – make it a part of your routine.Carry a book with you. Whenever you have a dull moment in your day – while using public transport, waiting for an appointment or having a break – just pop out a paperback and bust through a few pages.Listen to audiobooks. It’s incredibly simple and convenient. You can listen to them almost everywhere – while driving, while walking, while working out, while cooking…wherever.The Dangers of Reading The biggest danger to reading is that you won’t apply the knowledge. You have to put what you’ve read into use, otherwise it’s pointless to invest so much time into it. Instead, I read so that I could apply the knowledge learned into my life. You don’t want to just comprehend – you want to get the wisdom and wisdom is knowledge that is put into use and gained through experience. You have to take action on what you’ve learned, otherwise it can’t be said that you’ve actually understood it. There’s a very important concept I’m about to share with you – it’s speed of implementation. In essence, it’s about taking action as soon as possible and not waiting for the perfect moment. This way you’re not only increasing your learning curve but will also get more results. In 2016 I read over 300 books in total. It was the most successful year of my life so far because I not only speed read but also put that knowledge into action. Check out my video how I did it:  If you want to get tips for speed-reading, then read my blog: http://siimland.com/read-300-books-this-year Stay Smart, Stay Empowered!Siim

I wrote a dissertation on intelligence testing in the U.S. And Mexico. It is a misconception that intelligence is fixed. A particularly interesting study of 8th graders followed over decades found swings of 20–30 points in IQ were not uncommon. What explained that? Largely the intellectual stimulation they received. Kids who quit school at 8th grade and became ditch diggers showed drops in IQ while the average kid who stayed in school through medical school saw his IQ rise. What can you do? Stay in school. I’m 59 years old and have four degrees including a Ph.D. And I try to take a course at least once a year. Recently, I completed a course in responsive web design. You can take classes at the community college, online, at a local coding boot camp. It doesn’t have to cost you a lot of money. I have a subscription to Lynda: Online Courses, Classes, Training, Tutorials and take classes on that because it interests me. I'm currently taking a course in Spanish, too. Read. A lot. If you hate to read, then read a little until it gets easier. Watch documentaries. There are tons of them free on youtube, on fedflix (the government site), I think there is even an inexpensive documentary channel on line. Hang out with intelligent people. Your local library probably has book groups you can join, your local university probably has public lectures. When I taught at a couple of major universities they would have the most amazing people speak and I was always surprised how few people turned up.

There are 2 people who have achieved amazing results at improving the way people's brain works.  Daniel Amen who studies brain scans and Barbara Arrowsmith-Young who pioneered a method of classifying individual capabilities in such a way that these could be trainable. Here are their 2 very different Ted Talks.     The common thread to both of them is how to find and fix defects in the brain. It is the fixing of defects that produce the fastest and most astonishing results. While this is a common thread, their methodologies are very different. One studies the anatomical structure of brains, the other studies the visible capabilities of people based on what things they can and can't do. Both talks are very apropos and worth listening to, as they tell a story of major advancement with highly specific regimens that are personalized and diagnostic, not one-size-fits-all in nature. But if your brain is already working normally, with no particular defect, then taking it to a new higher level is an ongoing and slow process, one I've been engaged with my entire adult life. But I engage in this out of an interest in continuous improvement, not out of any particular IQ limiting need. The issue to be aware of, before undertaking this ongoing effort is that people are rarely IQ limited in life.  What we know from studying competitive fields, even apparently IQ focused fields like chess, physics, business, finance, investing, is that the top levels are achieved by people who have an over-the-top interest in the field and who practice a particular form of focused practice and study. This concept is outlined in the book: Talent Is Overrated by Geoff Colvin. The whole modern word is set up to make it easy to not need a very high IQ to make your way in life. Even fields like computer science are filled with tools designed to reduce the cognitive load involved in solving hard problems. Even so, here's what you do to advance those skills. First look at both of the talks I pointed you at, and find out more about both of those speakers. I've read many books by them and about them, and never been disappointed, always learned something useful. Beyond their highly directed information, my general purpose approach is to push myself regularly into areas that are difficult for me, and keep pushing myself until the formerly difficult becomes easy, or until I reach a point of vastly diminishing returns. When I take tests, when I read, when I write, when I think, I try to push myself as far as I can. The only way I have to gauge the effectiveness of my approach is to pick up things that used to be hard for me and see how they are now, and most of the time what used to be hard has become easy. Still, nothing is perfect. It is very important to realize the overarching limitation of IQ. How many fingers am I holding up right now? What card am I thinking of? What stock is going to rise the most tomorrow? No pure think-tank IQ approach can answer these questions. You have to collect data, engage with the world, try things. There is one other thing that I was surprised about. My mind is pushed the furthest when I am running my own business, rather than when I am working for others.  And many of the most intelligent people I've ever met were all running small businesses. Once a business surpasses about 25 million in revenue the best approach is to delegate to experts, but prior to that time the wealth of the business usually isn't sufficient to afford good experts and do that effectively. So you often have to task switch constantly, think strategically, push yourself to the highest level. Hope this helps.

If you want to hack your IQ, reading dictionaries as suggested is a fine idea. Improving cognitive load is at the heart of that sort of thing, and it's definitely useful. However, I've found that hacking your personality is more at the core of becoming ~smarter~ (in this instance, I mean more capable). Reading is very important. Very, very, very important. Everyone I know who I deeply admire reads a lot, and that's because they have the imagination and abstract-thinking abilities that come from reading. The knowledge in the books almost seems like a byproduct of the real gift you're getting, which is how to think. However, note that having a larger vocabulary than most people is just going to make it harder to communicate with the world. Instead, try expanding your every-day working vocabulary. Push yourself to express your ideas eloquently and powerfully. Become a strong communicator, because really, what else is language good for? Most importantly (in my opinion), seek solutions. Seek knowledge. Looking up words and ideas is a good start, but it doesn't seem like the fastest way to build real-life skills that can utilize your current IQ. Google or otherwise find the answers to any questions you have. Find fields or areas in your life that excite you, and deeply pursue those, no matter how trivial they are. The more you do that, the broader your interests will grow.  If you wonder about which route to work or school is faster, conduct experiments. If you wonder about anything, conduct experiments. Get in the habit of questioning and then, most importantly, following through. Don't just identify problems, find their solutions. The more you do this, the better you'll get at it, and I can't imagine a more useful skill, if only because of how broadly applicable it is to be able to break down any sort of problem into components, and then solve it. Part of IQ is cognitive load (short-term memory) and that can be improved by learning new words, sure, but another part is pattern matching. And when it comes to real-world applicability, the latter seems far more useful.

I recently did a semi-scientific analysis to answer just this question. Well, almost this question. I looked at which lifestyle choices most affect cognitive performance. The analysis was for my job as a scientist at Cambridge Brain Sciences, which is a tool for tracking lifestyle and cognitive performance. Cognitive performance isn't quite the same thing as IQ, but it's more important. Your performance changes from day to day, while IQ is generally thought of as more long-term. But I think cognitive performance matters more, because it results in advice better than "be born with good genes and never get sick or injured." When focusing on performance, you can take steps so your brain is at its very best every day, which results in doing more with it, including scoring higher on an IQ test, if that's what floats your boat. Here are the results of my analysis. They're roughly prioritized from highest impact to lowest, based on strength of scientific evidence, widespread applicability, and public interest. Sleep. You'll do better at cognitive tasks the next day after the right amount of good sleep, plus it has long-term protective effects that science is just starting to discover. Exercise. And it goes beyond just getting healthier, which is good for your brain too, obviously. For example, some people do better at brain tests immediately after certain physical activities.Stress. More isn't always worse. A medium amount of stress is usually best for your brain's performance. Mood. Not to be confused with stress, mood can boost or hinder your immediate performance, depending on if you're happy or sad, excited or calm. A lot of other interventions really only work indirectly by putting you in a better mood.Social interaction. Dealing with people can be harder than an IQ test. Avoiding loneliness and regularly spending time with others has been associated with better cognitive performance, especially going into old age. Caffeine and alcohol. Pretty obvious, but finding the right amounts to take or avoid can be tricky. Long-term effects are not always clear either; is caffeine really perking you up, or just bringing you back to where you were before you got addicted?Hydration. A lot of people don't drink enough water, but it can really help. Music consumption. Music can be a distraction or a pick-me-up, depending on the genre and tempo. It may just be an artifact of mood changes, though; playing Mozart for your baby probably won't increase her IQ. Meditation. Science is still fully figuring it out, but there are promising results for certain types of meditation.Nootropics. Smart drugs or supplements are a bit of an unknown. Certain substances do have evidence behind them (someone mentioned blueberries earlier, which have promise), but it's easy to waste money on snake oil if you don't actually seek out scientific evidence and test to see what works for you.Notice that commercial brain training isn't on there. I won't say it can't work, but science has not found a method that does work yet, except when combined with one of the factors above. Of course, not every one of these lifestyle factors will work for everyone. They depend on your current cognitive ability, the specifics of how you implement each one, your age, etc. If you're curious about the relationship between your lifestyle and your brain, you might want to check out Cambridge Brain Sciences (full disclosure: as I mentioned, I'm a staff scientist there). Our service lets you monitor your brain health over time, while tracking high-priority lifestyle habit—like sleep, stress, and exercise—so you can get clues about how your lifestyle is affecting your brain.

By “raise IQ”, I’ll assume you really mean increase biological intelligence, not cheat on an IQ test. My understanding is that a person can’t really increase his innate biological intelligence. What is possible, however, is to create an environment conducive to maximal brain health. Here are a few things you can do to maximize brain health: Physical exercise, especially aerobic exercise, is associated with “improvements” in fluid intelligence (Can Physical Activities Improve Fluid Intelligence? ). Exercise that involves coordinated movement also seems to help.You can improve your diet. One way is by getting enough essential omega-3 fatty acids eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) into your diet. However, eating more fish is neuroprotective even when you control for the effect of increased omega-3-fatty acid levels in the blood. Increase your intake of polyphenols, found in cranberries, blueberries, grapes, cocoa, etc. Two dietary interventions which have also been found to help are caloric restriction and intermittent fasting. Proceed with caution if you want to go down that road.Reduce negative stress in your life. You can kill two birds with one stone by doing aerobic exercise, since it helps you to physiologically respond much better to stress. You can also reduce stress by meditating. You can try meditation on steroids, or neurofeedback, if that is more your style (Want to Raise Your IQ by 23 Percent? Neuroscience Says Take Up This Simple Habit).Increase the love in your life. By this I mean maintain a rich and supportive social network.Sleep more. Sleep deprivation reduces neurogenesis and increases neuroinflammation.Here is an open source paper from which I pulled a lot of this advice: Neuroplasticity and Clinical Practice: Building Brain Power for Health Last but not least: I’m not a medical doctor, a psychologist, or a neuroscientist.

Q: “What are some of the best proven ways I can increase my IQ/Intelligence?” First define the purpose of the mind. The purpose of the mind is to perceive, to pose, and to resolve problems related to survival. Notice there is no “to prove” in this purpose. If one wished “to prove”, or a subject, wished “to prove” something, what means would they have other than using the mind itself? Second, define the word intelligence. I believe the closest fitting definition to the purpose of the mind, for the word intelligence, is this one: Intelligence is the ability to perceive, to pose, or to resolve problems related to survival. So you could examine two or more people and their ability to perceive and resolve problems related to survival. One might rate one better than the other. One person might look at a problem and see something no one else sees. He resolves the problem. Shall we rate him or her more “intelligent” than the others? I had this happen to me one day. I was asked to look at a problem, that had not ever been solved. The person that asked me, said that he had asked (that means he paid them) 5 mathematicians to solve this problem, and they could not. He thought he might try an Engineer. I looked at it and gave him my solution. He did not quite like what I had written. After the fifth revision of this written solution, he was satisfied. I had seen something the other five had not, and I had solved it. He could finally see, that I had indeed solved it. Except, I was now the one who understood what he had received a patent for. I gave him 13 more continuing patent disclosures on his own patent. One person might be good at posing a problem or framing a problem for others to solve. I had this happen to me one day. Boeing Aircraft Company called me up one day and asked me (our company) to stop by and look at a problem they were having with their newest aircraft. Their Engineers had not been able to solve it. I looked at the problem and understood the problem, but had no immediate solution. So, when I got back to our company I asked three Engineers, one by one, how they would solve it. I described the problem, I posed Boeing’s problem, and they understood the problem, but did not see a solution, or even that it was solvable. Each one happened to say, “You can’t have your cake and eat too.” I was hoping they would solve it for me, as I had no immediate solution either. But I did believe that it could be solved. So I looked at it depth, more like an Inventor would, more like Edison trying 10,000 things before solving the light bulb, and inventing something that works, than an Engineer just plugging in standard solutions. Finally, I had it. I worked out a drawing for Boeing to show them what it would look like. I made a graph to show how it worked. I took it to Boeing and they agreed that was what was needed. But they had not really believed our company could solve what Boeing Engineers had not, so they had just moved on. The aircraft was already moving onto the production line with the problem, not solved. That airplane still has that problem. A certain noise, a 60 hertz (cycles per second) buzz at exactly the same speed the engine is turning, when the aircraft is cruising at altitude when everyone wants it to be the most quite, so they can get some sleep. They said they could live with that. So here are the ways to improve IQ that I would recommend to you, if you wish to observe something for yourself, or others. Or if you wish to pose, or to frame a solution for others. You have to use two-way communications. For example, I might say, “Look at that wall.” Then I look at the person to see what they do. If they do not do it, I might say, “I’ll say that again, Look at that wall.” When they have done it, then they might say, “Okay.” Then I would say, “Thank you.” Two-way, a communication goes to them, and then a communication comes from them to me. So the idea is that excellent positive communications, two-way communications, and good control are the effective means. All that may only takes a second. Then your repeat for another wall. The exact wording of what to do, not so much. If a teacher or another student, does this for a entire class, for from 3 to 5 minutes, it has been shown to increase IQ by 5 points average for the class. I did this one time in the Air Force and a man said, “I feel like a light bulb!” Meaning he felt much smarter. That would be a good time to stop. It is really very easy and really light, when it is done right. Too much tension, not good. I would not consider this as a permanent change in intelligence, like some other methods. I would not expect it to work, if the teacher or student had not used good two-way communications, and ended off when the students were very bright and alert. There is a correct time to stop, to get the best results. Without two-way communications I would not expect anyone to improve IQ. Now, each of the means I suggest are in fact repairing when two-way communications have gone wrong in the past. For example, one study by Terman, The Genetic Study of Genius, used 1500 students with IQ’s of 140 or above. He found in six years that his students had lost an average of 9 points of IQ based on his Stanford-Binet Intelligence Test, or on his Terman Test. So that is 1.5 points of IQ lost per year of public school. Later research in Johannesburg South Africa about 1960, showed that this IQ loss in schools was occurring each year of school. And that when people located the words the students went past each year, and carefully defined them, the IQ for that year, returned. This is year by year. IQ lost, IQ returned. So a technique was developed to return all of this lost IQ due to words. In Terman’s study the kids were very high IQ, so I estimate that for more normal students that the loss is 1.0 points of IQ per year of public school, including college. So for a high school graduate that would be K-12 or 13 years, or 13 points of IQ loss on the average. For a four-year college graduate, K-16, that would be 17 points of IQ, on the average. Again, there was a failure of communications where the student failed to understand a word, IQ lost. The word was located and properly defined, so the student now, does understand. IQ returns. You can do ‘before and after’ IQ tests on this, and when the technique is used, this is normally done. So there is lots of experience with this. 10’s of thousands of people have done this. I have done this, I have received this. The technique is called Method One Word Clearing, or M1. For high school student I would say it would take 8 to 16 hours on the average. For college students, a good deal longer. It is normally done as the first action on a study course called, The Student Hat Course. That course teaches you how to study properly and avoid this loss in intelligence, and many, many other things. You should be flying along feeling brilliant after that course. There is a book you can read. It has exercises you can do. My wife and I read this book to each other and the family. The book is: Self Analysis: L. Ron Hubbard: 9781403144102: Amazon.com: Books The goal of that book is to improve your memory and emotional level. I estimate your reaction time will improve. I estimate if you do these exercises exactly per the book, that would increase your IQ. Again, excellent communications are the key, they are vital. You can do before and after IQ tests with this too. If you read these exercises to another for an hour a day, for 40 days, and another reads to you for and hour a day for 40 days, you should see measurable results on your before and after IQ tests. You should be able to measure the change in your emotional level every week or so, say every 8 or 10 hours. The basic way to improve intelligence is to remove pain from the mind. About one in three million people on Earth do not record pain in their minds. They never have recorded pain. They experience pain, but it is not in their minds. Pain is the basic thing one tends to avoid in the mind. These people have photographic memories, actually eidetic memories. But this is not the way this thing about pain was worked out and developed. See the book: Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health: L. Ron Hubbard: 9781403144843: Amazon.com: Books Chapter Two describes something called a Clear. This is a person that has erased the pain in their own minds. The people that have never recorded pain as a perception, are called Natural Clears. These people have a minimum IQ of 135. I estimate an average of 150 to 160 IQ for Clears. There are 10’s of thousands of people that have “gone Clear.” This technology is well proven. One can take a person with an IQ of 70 and Clear them. Their IQ will rise to at least 135. I don’t know how long that might take, but with the technology today, it can be done. Best regards, Leon

How have you gotten such a high IQ? I was born with it for the most part; almost entirely. That’s the fact. As much as 85% of intelligence is heredity and most of the rest is prenatal or very early childhood. [My sister (who is a physicist and smarter than me by a bunch) told me yesterday that when I was 3 I had an intuitive grasp of Physics and explained that if I could fall off the toilet due to gravity pulling me down there must be something pushing me up on the toilet. I have no recollection of that discussion. Perhaps she read more into my answer than I actually intended…] It seems unfair. Well it is I suppose. But Michael Jordan was born with the ability to be perhaps the greatest BBall player ever. He had to apply it and develop it; but the court is not level. He was born that way. I can envy him or admire him but it doesn’t change anything. (And I’m not in THAT league in terms of intelligence!) I put my pants on one leg at a time. I have to clean house and cook dinner and weed he garden. My life isn’t that much different. Before I retired I had a boss and other people who told me what to do or what I could do, etc. On the other hand please believe me when I say that, while being smart is pretty nice and I wouldn’t give it up, I don’t really see it as making me all that different. I am different in other ways. I worked a long career with lots of people who weren’t quite so smart but who knew their stuff and made effective partners in achieving things worth doing. (And at least a few who were smarter than me…) For all practical purposes they knew things I didn’t and my being “smarter” was often irrelevant. They are friends, colleagues and in my mind equals. I bet most of them don’t know how smart I am and think I’m at their level. Most of the time it never occurred to me that I might be smarter as a matter of fact. I have no disrespect for anyone based on their level of innate intelligence. I might as well complain about their eye color. I imagine Michael might be dissatisfied if he was teamed up with me for real, But then that wouldn’t have ever happened. I won’t go into the negatives, because that’s a bell rung too often plus it’s just silly, the positives far outweigh them and they aren’t as bad as people think. And not by any stretch universal. Don’t be jealous of someone’s innate abilities your value as a person is most enhanced by how you use what you do have. Even average intelligence is an awesome amount of brainpower.

First, let me say that I’m not an expert on raising IQ. Moreover, I believe IQ is more limited in terms of its actual utility than one might think. General intelligence, which may or may not be measured in part or whole by IQ, is probably one of the most important single attributes you can strive to increase or maintain. Ditto for IQ. However, there are other attributes like empathy, knowledge, wisdom, curiosity, intellectualism that are also important and sometimes are more so in different circumstances. Two quick examples before I directly answer the question: (1) Someone with high IQ but no motivation or curiosity probably won’t be as “smart” as someone with high motivation and a hunger to learn with a lower IQ in the run. I think we all know a lot of really high IQ people that sometimes have challenges coping. (2) In many ways both ends of Bell Curve share many sometimes superficial similarities. So, IQ isn’t everything though it’s still a great thing to improve. Here are some scientifically reputable ways to improve IQ (and also memory, cognition, and other important traits) in no particular order: (1) Play puzzle games like Sudoku or take logic tests. Games like Magic The Gathering are also great thinking activities and social. I played that a lot when I was younger and it was a blast. (2) Stay healthy - you don’t need to have a lot of muscle - just stay active, avoid sitting for more than 30–45 minutes in a row, give you heart and body some activity. (3) Try some spices like Cumin - that one, in particular has been shown to grow brain cells. Caffeine is also good for a quick increase in alertness (and IQ) as long as you don't take too much. (4) Get good sleep - the brain washes out the connections between neurons when you sleep. Too little and you get build up that can contribute to Alzheimer's and memory loss. (5) Keep stress down by doing things that make you happy, keep strong but not superficial relationships, and don’t smoke marijuana. Doing the opposite can reduce IQ over long periods of time. Keeping many friends is also great but people who lack strong support groups can be detrimentally impacted by stress. (6) Make good decisions. No matter how high your IQ is, it doesn’t if you’re extremely foolish. One must be humble and want to learn to benefit from their IQ no matter what it is. Small changes are great - making one small but smarter change ever day and sticking to it can have huge improvements over a year and life equal to it greater than improvements to IQ. Changes also help to keep one’s perspective fresh. What use is being smart if all you do is EXACTLY the same thing each and every day? We want IQ and being smart to pay off and IMPROVE our lives but the main way for that to happen is to APPLY it in new ways (sorry for the all caps). I’ll add more here if I encounter or think of any!

20 or 30 years ago perhaps, there was a lot of popular science discussion going on about to which degree intelligence is hereditary and to which degree it is not. Today, these waters have calmed down. Still, the popular perception persists that intelligence is a known entity which can be measured like you measure time, distance, or body height. The answer below about Mark and John is an example of that misconception. But what we call intelligence is a heuristically conceived, not well defined, quite shadowy concept which has a certain use value in certain situations, but not more. It is used so much because a psychological industry, makes us believe into a concreteness which does not really exist.Given this, of course anyone can, and has to develop those talents which we tend to subsume under intelligence (or not): take a musical gift: if you don't have access to an instrument, if you don't find a competent teacher, your talent is likely to wither away.  And people who have a particular gift often strive to develop this, search for chances to improve themselves. And there are geniuses, certainly, in music, poetry, painting, mathematics, philosophy, learning languages, presenting themselves, (mis)leading other people or mediating between them, whatever. Some have multiple talents, some only one, and others just get well through this maze we call life, not becoming famous, but gaining satisfaction from a well-groomed family life, friends, by knowing when to sow and when to harvest, and when to pray. Some routinely cheat in a very inventive way, and make a living from that.All this has been called intelligence - but what do you gain by subsuming all these qualities under one name?  If I would take more time, I might go into Foucault's notion of discourse to elucidate how much a cultural concept intelligence really is, how much is is linked to, yes, well, power, but also modern definitions of the self, grooming those individual values we tend to think about as paramount.

There are primary elements involved in increasing your fluid intelligence, or cognitive ability. It would be impractical to constantly practice the dual n-back task or variations thereof every day for the rest of your life to reap cognitive benefits. But it isn’t impractical to adopt lifestyle changes that will have the same—and even greater cognitive benefits. These can be implemented every day, to get you the benefits of intense entire-brain training, and should transfer to gains in overall cognitive functioning as well. These five primary principles are:1. Seek Novelty2. Challenge Yourself3. Think Creatively4. Do Things The Hard Way5. Network Also to increase your productivity and improve intellect level : 1. Minimize Television Watching –  The problem is watching television doesn’t use your mental capacity OR allow it to recharge. It’s like having the energy sapped out of a muscle without the health benefits of exercise. When you feel like relaxing, try reading a book instead. If you’re too tired, listen to some music. When you’re with your friends or family, leave the tube off and have a conversation. All of these things use your mind more than television and allow you to relax. 2. Exercise – I used to think that I’d learn more by not exercising and using the time to read a book instead. But I realized that time spent exercising always leads to greater learning because it improves productivity during the time afterwards. Using your body clears your head and creates a wave of energy. Afterwards, you feel invigorated and can concentrate more easily. 3. Read Challenging Books – Many people like to read popular suspense fiction, but generally these books aren’t mentally stimulating. If you want to improve your thinking and writing ability you should read books that make you focus. Reading a classic novel can change your view of the world and will make you think in more precise, elegant English. Don’t be afraid to look up a word if you don’t know it, and don’t be afraid of dense passages. Take your time, re-read when necessary, and you’ll soon grow accustomed to the author’s style.Once you get used to reading challenging books, I think you’ll find that you aren’t tempted to go back to page-turners. The challenge of learning new ideas is far more exciting than any tacky suspense-thriller. 4. Early to Bed, Early to Rise – Nothing makes it harder to concentrate than sleep deprivation. You’ll be most rejuvenated if you go to bed early and don’t sleep more than 8 hours. If you stay up late and compensate by sleeping late, you’ll wake up lethargic and have trouble focusing. In my experience the early morning hours are the most tranquil and productive. Waking up early gives you more productive hours and maximizes your mental acuity all day.If you have the opportunity, take 10-20 minute naps when you are hit with a wave of drowsiness. Anything longer will make you lethargic, but a short nap will refresh you. 5. Take Time to Reflect – Often our lives get so hectic that we become overwhelmed without even realizing it. It becomes difficult to concentrate because nagging thoughts keep interrupting. Spending some time alone in reflection gives you a chance organize your thoughts and prioritize your responsibilities. Afterwards, you’ll have a better understanding of what’s important and what isn’t. The unimportant stuff won’t bother you anymore and your mind will feel less encumbered. Conclusion – I hope you aren’t disappointed that none of the techniques I’ve proposed are revolutionary. But simple, unexciting answers are often the most valid. The challenge is having the will to adhere to them. If you succeed in following these 5 tips, you’ll be rewarded with increased mental acuity and retention of knowledge. 5 Simple Ways to Increase Your Intelligence | PickTheBrain | Motivation and Self ImprovementYou can increase your intelligence: 5 ways to maximize your cognitive potential | Guest Blog, Scientific American Blog Network

I apologize for this answer as it may upset some readers here, however the answer is no, you cannot increase your IQ, which is based upon some possibly ill conceived standard test. First of all, there are many “IQ tests” in the world, which one would you choose as being the correct one? An IQ score is made up from a standard test. A standard test asks things like how well do you understand that something like 1 plus 1 equals 2, or even something like, if today is Thursday, and Saturday is two days after Thursday, what is two days before Sunday? With the correct answer here being Friday, and you pick that as your test answer, you have shown some form of abstract thinking when it comes to the days of the week… and you can likely (at least) learn things about how the seven days in a week actually relate to each other when considering the day names. When giving regards to an IQ “score”, it really only indicates your possible potential for learning new things about common relationships between the days of the week (or other such mundane relationships). I hope that you can comprehend here in my explanation, why there is a possible gap between your learning possibilities, and your actual learning experiences. This is important when considering that you really cannot change your IQ score, because of the IQ score is coming from a standardized test. If you are stubborn and happen to disregard the notion that it really does matter that knowledge of which day of the week follows a given day of the week, and you refuse to learn that Friday follows Thursday and is two days before Sunday… then even though your IQ is rated “very high” because you got the test answer correct, your real life ability could be likely rated “really low”. This would be because your IQ test answer does not match up with your real life knowledge. So, I also hope this long and round about way of counting days of the week kind of explains that you cannot change your “standard IQ test score”, however, it’s fairly easy to change your “life knowledge score”, and recognize that these two things are never going to be one and the same thing. Best Regards and Good Luck! Fred Williams

The brain is the only sexy organ in the body which can do exceptional things in life using the physical body. Which power you want to increase? MemoryDecision MakingKeeping yourself relaxedPsychic powerLogical ThinkingVisualizationBrain StaminaConcentrationAbove are only few but there is many thing brain can do. Assuming that you need to increase the concentration power here is one practice that you can do daily- Tratak Sit in a comfortable chair (or on bed in cross leg position). In front of you, 3 feet apart from your eyes & at the same level as that of your eyes, place an object like a candle, or something bright, in the light background. Light background is essential. Place your hand in the dhyaan mudra i.e.meditative pose ( see below image) close eyes for few minutes and relax your body like this-  Take your consciousness rapidly to different organs of your body (Read Yoga Nidra if want to know more). Upper body- Relax your tip of the head > relax your forehead > relax your eyebrows > relax the middle of your eyebrows > your eyes relax > relax your ears, your cheeks, nose, both nostrils, higher lip, lower lip, chin.Middle body- Now relax your shoulders, both arms till the tip of the fingers > Now relax your armpit > relax your shoulder blades > your buttocks > Now relax your chest, middle of the chest, navel, abdomen > Now relax your waist completely.Lower body- Now relax your hips, your thighs, your knees, your lower legs, ankles, heels, sole of the foot, tips of your toes.NOW, slowly open your eyes and watch the object. Keep watching (don’t blink) until you feel that your eyes are straining or if tears are coming from your eyes. If yes, then close your eyes slowly.Close your eyes slowly and observe the image of that object in the middle of the eyebrows. (For more detail you can visit google)Various thoughts will appear, but its okay.If you feel that you can’t see the image open the eyes and observe the object again. Keep watching as mentioned in the step #1.If thoughts are appearing then its okay, they come and go like fragrance of a flower. You are a flower and they’re your fragrance. After 4 days of practice increase the time interval of Tratak for 5 more minutes & then after 4 days increase the duration of Tratak 5 more again… You can increase the duration after every 4 days or you can keep it constant (say 20 minutes) daily; that’s up to you. NOTE- while relaxing for the first time you may take more than 5 minutes, but its okay… With your daily practice you will start getting relaxed in 5 minutes.

an IQ is just a score on a specific test. It may or may not correlate with a score on a different test. The test can be useful in some circumstances, and should be performed by a trained professional, and ordered by a trained professional- such as a psychiatrist, a neurologist, or a provider with additional training. Few things will make you smarter- but getting adequate sleep, eating right, getting enough exercise, and managing your mental health and avoiding drugs is a good step. My parents were life long learners into their late 90s, and took courses in the local college (audit) or actually took for credit. My Aunt started law school upon retirement at 65 so she could fix her own parking tickets! My grandmother did a book group that picked a book for each meeting to read and discuss. My brother decided on a career change and went to architecture school at 40, and didn’t actually finish until 5 years later, My wife started law school in her late 40s, and did fine. It may not make you smarter, but it will broaden your world view, and open up possibilities that certainly will make you act smarter. You may not become a Marine, but you can become all that you can be, if you become a life long learner- you can maximize your potential. I used to own a Porsche- late 50s C. It had a 2 liter motor and only 90 horsepower—- but it was fun to drive and had a proud heritage on the race track. It wasn’t an Indy car or even class dragster, but a really cool car. Your 99 is certainly acceptable— roughly half of people on the test did better, and half did worse. You should be able to learn whatever you want, and accomplish great things with work. There is nothing wrong with starting out as average. If your friend with the “higher IQ doesn’t keep learning” and you do, you will soon know more that he does. which makes you better informed, more rounded, and in my view smarter. If you really want to test higher on an IQ test—- simply find out what test you are going to take—- then go on line or down to your local university bookstore and purchase the testing material or guidebook—- you might have to look a bit, but if you have the name of the test you will find it. With some practice, and the answers to the questions, you should be able to score a 200. I wouldn’t waste my money as you will not be smarter, but some people might think you are. I think you should attempt to broaden your horizons - be interested in the world, read a lot, and get involved in politics- our world needs a lot of help from all of us. If your friend doesn’t appreciate you, then he/she might not be as smart as they think. abc

5 Smart Ways to Increase Your IQ in a Month. Trust me your Intelligence will excel as you will work hard at least for a month.  1. Memory activities Reasoning and language are both used as intelligence measures, meaning that memory activities can continue to develop intelligence. jigsaw puzzlescrossword puzzlesconcentration card game, or card matchingsudoku 2. Executive control activities Research suggests that executive function is strongly tied to fluid reasoning, one aspect of human intelligence. Activities that involve executive control training include: ScrabblePictionaryred light, green lightbrainteasers3. Relational skills Relational Frame Theory relates to the development of human cognition and language through relational associations. Research from 2011 has shown that using Relational Frame Theory as an intervention can significantly improve IQ scores in children. A more recent study using this intervention also found improvements in IQ, verbal reasoning, and numeric reasoning. Activities that involve relational training include: language learning books (“this is a…” and “that is a…”)object comparisons (full cup versus empty cup)amount comparisons (penny versus dime)4. Musical instruments You don’t have to become the next famous musician to benefit from learning a musical instrument. One study found that musicians have a better working memory than non-musicians. Given the important role memory plays in intelligence, it may benefit your IQ to finally pick up that musical instrument you’ve always wanted to learn.  5. Frequent reading There’s no denying how beneficial books are in human cognitive development. In fact, the benefits of development are even more pronounced when books become part of parental bonding activities. In one recent study, researchers discovered that when parents read aloud to their children, the child had greater language and cognitive development skills.  All the Best. Work Hard and also if you are good in simple maths you are already smart.

I am not convinced you can raise your IQ even if you raise your actual score. An IQ test is, in my opinion, nothing more than a medium rough assessment of a person’s intellectual potential. We do not even have a good definition of intelligence so we cannot really say we know what we are actually measuring. The closest we can come to a definition is to say that intelligence is defined by your score on a standardized test, but such a definition is what is known in logic as a tautology, a circular definition. The classic example of this is saying that “no true Scotsman drinks anything but single malt whisky. McDougal drinks blended whisky therefore he is no true Scotsman.” Here we say that what shows intelligence? Answer: a high score on an intelligence test. How do we know that the test measures intelligence? Only smart people do well on IQ tests. How do we know they are smart? They do well on IQ tests. Having said this, it is certainly possible to increase your score on IQ tests. If you do such things as ensuring good test conditions (adequate lighting, comfortable chairs, no distractions), practice taking the exams, eating well, ensuring you are well hydrated and getting lots of rest the night before,you may test better, but this does not establish that your actual intellectual potential has increased. Practice, for example, may increase your speed through familiarity alone and IQ tests are timed so more speed will increase your score somewhat, but not a lot. Think of it like this. If you lack the raw talent for a sport, say basketball, you may gain some proficiency from training and practice that might lead someone who did not know that you have never practiced to credit you with more raw talent than you actually possess, but you will not have increased you fund of talent, yo will only have.made the most of what you have. A person with lots of raw talent will get much farther with exactly the same amount of training and practice. There is no evidence that I am aware of that show great increases in IQ scores from any type of training or practice though there may be some quite modest improvement. Anyone who takes the test multiple times will show both increases and decreases in scores among the tests taken, but this is probably foe to random variations in test conditions and the condition of the subject.

With few life hacks, you may be able to boost your IQ by one standard deviation. Challenge your brain by breaking your routines, reading, solving puzzles, and seeking new experiences to increase your IQ. Supplement your efforts by getting plenty of protein, vitamin B, and rest, all of which enhance your brain's ability to remain alert. The right diet and lifestyle can do wonders. Are you ready? Part1 Changing Your Routine 1Do everyday things differently. Challenge your brain to form new connections and pathways by doing the things you normally do on autopilot differently. Brush your teeth with your non-dominant hand. Walk around as if you’re going backwards through time. Talk to yourself in a different language. Whatever you can do to mix it up, do it!Doing this forms new pathways and connections in your brain. Quite often we take for granted how easy life is, especially once we get the basics down. When you mix it up, your brain has to relearn the skill, challenging it all the more.2Meditate. Much research has shown that not only is meditating good for stress levels and mood, but it’s also good for brain functioning.[1] It has been shown to improve blood flow to the brain, patience, concentration, and memory. And it's totally relaxing, too.Try 30 minutes each day. You may split this into 10 or 15 minute blocks 2-3 times a day. It is preferable to do when you wake up, after you exercise, and at night directly before you go to bed.3Consider taking supplements. A much safer alternative to taking "smart" drugs is taking natural supplements. Just make sure you're taking the right amount by talking to your doctor first. All of the ones below come backed by scientific research:Caffeine[2]Creatine[3]Ginkgo Biloba[4]Omega-3 fatty acids[5]4Start doing regular aerobic exercise. The studies of Win Wenger show that breath correlates to attention span. Try underwater swimming or running. If not, any aerobic exercise should do. Exercise twice a day for 45 minutes when you wake up and before you go to bed. You should preferably couple this with meditation after you exercise.This is good for your waistline, too, and fitness, in turn, can improve your mood. The more endorphins you release in your exercise sessions, the more active your brain is and the better you'll feel.5Sleep when your brain actually wants it. Some people are in their prime thinking zone at 9 in the morning. Some at 9 at night. Even others at 3 AM or whenever they’ve finished their third cup of coffee. Since everyone is different, sleep when your brain wants it. Do you do your best work at night? Then sleep late. You’re not being lazy, you’re being wise!Aim to get a solid 7-9 hours of sleep a night, too. When you're tired, your brain can't function at 100%. It cuts down what it thinks it can, sort of putting you in hibernation mode, and only does what it absolutely has to to keep you alive and breathing. Consistent inadequate sleep also prevents your brain from developing to its full potential, and can lead to various mental and physical illnesses down the line.Part2 Practicing Your Skills 1Read more. Genetics aside, education is a big factor contributing to your IQ. Try reading up on the sciences, such as mathematics and physics. Sciences increase your understanding of the world, which in turn improves comprehension, vocabulary, spatial and mathematical abilities, and logic.You can try MIT OpenCourseware, which offers notes, syllabuses, and tests from over 1800 official MIT courses. You can also go for Coursera, KhanAcademy, or even YouTube.2Do word puzzles and problem-solving games. To stave off dementia and to keep your brain churning away at high speeds, make sure to do puzzles and games regularly – which means (in this day and age) more time on the Internet and your phone! Download apps like Lumosity[6], What Saying, Quiz Up, and other games that get your brain juices flowing. Put down the Candy Crush and spend some time instead improving your IQ!The Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale and the Stanford-Binet do not measure intelligence in a single, simple form. Rather, they have a set of problems which measure your ability to process things quickly, understand what you are told, and recognize sequences. [7]3Take the tests over and over. Just like that chemistry test you had to take four times in high school to pass, IQ tests aren’t all that different. They have the same basic structure and types of questions over and over. Therefore, the more you take it, the better you’ll do.The tests you can take for free online aren't like the actual tests you might take through a career center or a psychiatrist. If you want your real IQ, you'll have to take the real thing. There is generally a fee, so always try your hardest.4Get new experiences. When you do the same thing day in and day out, the brain sort of goes on autopilot. It stops taking in stimuli, comfortable in its surroundings. When you have new experiences though, the brain wakes up and takes it all in, revving up for a change. So instead of popping in that DVD tonight, find a museum, a show, or a new place to check out to keep your mental clock ticking wildly.Even just visiting a new place or trying a new food is a good experience. You're widening your knowledge, making yourself better informed for future decisions. However, the more different they are, the better. Consider it an excuse for an exotic vacation!5Teach yourself something new. Actively learning new things helps your brain learn and may help you make connections that before were not possible. Learning a new skill such as how to play chess or lacrosse, how to juggle, or anything you've never done before for that matter – may help your brain in ways you never even dreamed of.[8]Learning another language is a great way to get the brain working on new pathways. Not only does it fire up centers in your brain that aren't being used, but it's real-world applicable and impressive to boot.Part3 Changing Your Diet 1Eat plenty of protein for breakfast. Protein has the ability to increase your brain’s production of neurotransmitters, and increases norepinephrine and dopamine levels in turn – all of which increases your alertness and problem-solving skills.This is especially important for breakfast to get you ready and raring to go for the day. Sugar for breakfast just leads to a crash in a couple of hours, slowing you down, and leaving you even hungrier than before.2Snack on dark chocolate.[9] Dark chocolate is full of antioxidants and loaded with flavonols. It’s also high in magnesium, vitamins A, B1, B2, D, and E.3 It's a powerhouse of antioxidants that helps fight off free radicals. This makes sure our bodies stay healthy and strong.Not too much though, of course. Anywhere between 1 and 5 ounces a day is good.3Get more vitamin B. This little nutrient increases blood flow to the brain.[10] You can find vitamin B in green, leafy vegetables, whole wheat, meat, eggs, and cheese. Just be sure that you don't get too much either! Talk to your doctor about the appropriate amount for you.Folic acid, riboflavin, thiamine, and niacin are all part of the structure of vitamin B. When you get vitamin B, you get a powerhouse of goodies all in one.4Avoid processed and junk foods. Many studies have shown that a healthy diet is linked to a higher IQ, especially in children. To keep your brain firing on all pistons, stay away from junk food like cookies and chips and processed food – do the cooking at home to help your brain and your budget.[11]Vegetarians have higher IQs on the whole, by about 5 points for both sexes.[12] To get the extra boost, make "Meatless Monday" a regular thing throughout the week.5Consider fasting intermittently. IF, or intermittent fasting, has been shown to lead to increased brain power and higher level functioning. [13] IF is where you don’t eat for 16 hours, and eat plenty for 8. It may or may not mean caloric restriction, depending on how you do it.You can also use this technique to manage your weight. Many fast intermittently and see great results in terms of weight loss. Just make sure you're doing it safely – fasting isn't for everyone (the elderly, expecting mothers, young children, etc.).hope you guys liked thoes ways please upvote and follow me and also comment more stuff i know there's more but just takes along time to write but i will write more and please request answers from me please.

In my experience, the most important thing is to find something that interests you and read about it. I, myself, wouldn’t read about carpentry because I’m terrible at it, and doing or learning about something you’re terrible can affect your self-esteem (it might also make you better at something you’re terrible at). If something fascinates you, start reading about it and if you enjoy reading about it you’ll want to read more. As you read you’ll likely find more subjects that peek your interest, so you can start reading about them too. After a while you might have enough ideas and material tucked away in your head to write a book! As you read you can start making connections between the knowledge you’ve accumulated from various fields. Working on those connections can help you create unique perspectives or theories that have real value in the world. This is how Elon Musk came up with some of his most valuable contributions. I started out reading about subjects that not only interested me, but that promised to help me understand life, why I act and feel a particular way in different situations. I wanted to understand what the underlying master-code was to human motivations and dysfunctions. Having suffered from depression for much of my life I determined that I was not willing to spend my twilight years feeling anxious and sad, so my goal has always been to find the way to inner peace. I’ve been working on the draft of my first book for the past two years. It draws together many of the things I’ve learned in a way that I think will help other people, but there’s a whole lot more I want to say, so other books are in the works. If you think these ideas sound good but you don’t have the motivation to follow up on them, find someone who is happy to help you get over the procrastination phase. Make yourself accountable to them, kinda like a workout partner who will push you to get that 10th repetition lifting the dumbbells. Best of luck!

My qualifications: for example: I flunked out of high-school, but when I took the SATs, I scored high above 99 percentile.  When I took the GED, I got the highest scores the administrator had ever seen.  When I took college entrance exams, they let me skip first-year requirements.  As a writing tutor at UC Berkeley, I developed an essay-writing-and-comprehsion technique that enables virtually anyone to get “A”s on in-class essays.  In my “alternative” children’s programs, I pioneered “hands on” learning in the early 1980s - what I call “interest-based learning,” to promote what I call “comprehension-developement” - using direct learning in simple material relationships to help children develop confidence in their own perceptions.  This is generally remedial work, counteracting what goes on in most schools, where adult impatience or conformist notions train children to perceive a fuzzy, compromising tension as the be-all and end-all of knowing.  I know what intelligence is, and I know how to improve it - and I assume the difference would register on IQ tests.  My advice is in two simple points. 1.)  Learn to trust your own grasp of plain logic or reason.Intelligence is muddled by a lifetime of emotional pressues to see things in a prescribed way.  Learn to “believe in” plain logic, no matter how unusual the results may be.  You don’t have to be quick; take your time and be simple.  I have never been quick with basic math, but when elaborate problems are presented to large groups, to see who can solve them first, I almost always win - by taking my time - one part of the problem at a time - clearly - one simple step at a time. I disagree with those who say life’s topics are complex.  No, they’re all simple.  Sure there’s a special kind of “genius” with amazing memory or ability to multiply large numers instantly, but the real genius is not the person who can manage complexities; he’s the one who sees the simplicity at the root of apparent complexity - the “genie” of the thing - in a habit of letting nothing deter him from a comfortable grasp of the obvious.  For example: “the complexities of the Middle East conflict” have often been cited, along with rocket-science, as beyond ordinary grasp.  Yet, a quick overview shows a plain and basic fact: an expressly “Jewish” state is being forced ever deeper into a primarily Arab, Muslim, and Christian region.  It does not take a rocket scientist to see that violent racism does not occur in plainer form than that - and that sort of thing would naturally have grave regional consequences - endlessly complex, but all organized in relation to the initial ethnic-cleansing, like the branches and leaves of a simple tree.  It’s a good example also because we’re all under a lot of political and social pressure to not see that simple problem at the very root.  It’s “hard to believe” something so obvious could pass so unnoticed, but the highly intelligent person commonly overrides that notion.  Intelligence must be independent - tuned only to the basics, and always free to change if new data suggests new conclusions or theories.  The intelligent person will often “disagree” with mainstream notions, but will minimize conflict with them. Consistent with all that, stop getting upset when logic leads to conclusions you don’t like.  Make a quest to overcome those sub-rational drives.  Learn to follow reason freely, wherever it leads, and also learn to entertain new apparent conclusions, without getting dogmatic about them.  See the logic of the thing, rather than trying to form a conclusion.  Stick light-heartedly with apparent conclusions until better logic calls for modification.  All reason, throughout the universe, is logically interconnected: emotionally overriding logic, in order to cling to even just one pet notion, sends its tensions everywhere and diminishes free perception everywhere. Get used to seeing logic and comprehension in that easygoing, light-hearted way - no emotional agenda - simple service to reason. 2.) Exercise your discernment.Some music and movies, for example, are worthy of full attention from the most discerning minds.  Many of the best do not require any special refinement, but are quite accessible, and in many the special quality is flaming obvious, if given anyone’s full attention - and will heavily reward it when it’s provided.  But I mean full attention - not the usual thing.  So start with what you like, but now, just for fun, as part of this “exercising,” start looking for editing and camera-changes in movies, and start recognizing the movies that truly call for full attention.  Not all do, by any means; most modern mainstream movies do not, but put more active attention into noticing the difference, preferably reflecting objective values, not just personal preference.  So appreciate the fight-scenes that use special effects or movie-making tricks, for example, but also notice the difference when great fights show really great martial-arts, with little dependency on special-effects exaggerations. The point is to make a point of looking closer, discerning pro-actively.  Some very popular movies don’t reward that at all, so see the difference for yourself.  The same principle applies to music; listen with full attention; notice what you did not notice before.  Some works reward that way more than others - and seeing the difference is part of intelligence.  The effort is well worth it, in terms of sheer fun or “appreciation of life,” and exercising discernment increases intelligence in general. On perhaps a more personal note, well, we all have our favorite movies, but I just have to say I have never seen any that reward repeat viewings better than the first three Jason Bourne movies; in fact, I haven’t stopped being amazed at how much there is to discern in these movies - how much becomes apparent with repeat viewings - how much effort and seemingly awesome luck went into them.  I think my discernment has been considerably improved by seeing what I had missed before.  And - as is usually true in the smart things - a great deal of it is utterly obvious, yet is still commonly underappreciated.  In this case, it’s the locations (and the great ways they’re used), car-chases, and most of the martial arts - and everything in between.  Even the weapons are unusually cool, yet sensible.  There certainly are some flaws, but seeing the difference does not detract. Another answer to this question suggested getting more actively curious in general, and that’s right.  Pro-actively exploring what’s going on often produces fun results.  In fact, intelligence and fun - or appreciating life - are closely related.

The best way is to stop thinking about how smart you are or aren't and then to embrace challenges.  There's been a lot of research on this, and Carol Dweck is one of the earliest and most published researchers in the field.  She has a very accessible book that deals with this along with the subject of motivation: Self-theories: Their Role in Motivation, Personality, and Development (Essays in Social Psychology): 9781841690247: Medicine & Health Science Books @ Amazon.com The basic idea is that people tend to have one of two models of learning (it's probably more of a spectrum from one extreme to the other).  Those with a "fixed" model or "mindset" think that intelligence is fixed.  You can't improve it.  Such people tend to give up quickly when they can't solve a problem or learn something new.  They simply believe that they aren't smart enough in the particular learning context.  Fortunately for you, your question indicates that you're not a member of this group. Those with a "growth" model or mindset think that intelligence can be improved with practice and perseverance.  The research show that they are correct.  Dweck's research has shown that students with growth models of learning persevere longer on tasks, enjoy challenges, don't get upset when they can't figure something out right away or even for long periods of time and continuously get better at learning. I've had many students who illustrate this.  One such student simply never gave up on trying to solve even very difficult problems in physics, and he seldom wanted more than a small hint from me with even the most difficult problems.  He eventually figured out almost every challenging problem in introductory and advanced physics.  His fellow students all thought he was a genius.  However, while he often functions at genius level, once I really got to understand his approach to learning it was clear to me that he wasn't as intrinsically bright as many other students I've taught who didn't achieve as much. In retrospect I've realized that I had a growth model in learning science and math and a fixed model in the humanities.  Once I understood this, I changed my model concerning the humanities and started making much better progress in writing and in learning and enjoying history. Seek out mental challenges, try different approach to dealing with them when your first efforts don't work, persevere and enjoy the ride.  Your intelligence will grow.  You might not see much change at first, but since the effects are cumulative, in the long run you will see big changes.

I have an advanced degree in Psychology and I’ve been interested in how the mind works for decades. As far as I can determine, there is no way to increase I.Q. I.Q. is a number that represents the results of testing something that has no definition. In a way, it is like testing dark matter. What would you be testing? The gravitational effects on a galaxy? Would that be dark matter? No. I.Q. is much the same. Problem solving? Memory? Measuring something like I.Q. is like trying to sew together a jellyfish. Measure the I.Q. of an “idiot savant” and you get such low numbers you don’t know if he/she is even human, yet they can remember events going back thousands of years, calculate faster than a computer, play a piano without taking lessons, and on and on. The issue really isn’t the level of Intelligence Quotient, it is how well you utilize it. Believe me, there are a lot of people out there with high I.Q.s in their 40s who are still living in their mom’s basement. I shop at a supermarket that hires retarded kids as baggers and cleaners. Those kids work hard, try to please, and seem to be the happiest people in the store - and the most loving. You can see all that in their faces. They don’t count the money they make, they would probably be baggers for free just to enjoy the experience of working, being with people, and being useful. THAT is how to use intelligence.

Just read.Discuss what you read, make sure people challenge you, make sure you have to explain yourself to those who don’t understand. Discuss, discuss, discuss.When you are smart and articulate; you will be very successful no matter what you do, no matter what your IQ is (I do not have a college degree, no idea what my IQ is, and I cannot do any math as I never moved beyond 7th grade pre-algebra. I assure you that I am not suffering). When you are smart, articulate and charismatic, you’ll be rich whether you want to be or not. (you can define “rich” for yourself) Charisma is the ultimate quality of brilliance. Because people will like you and they will want to listen to you. IQ doesn’t mean shit with any of this. IQ is a fools errand. I know sales people.. sales people with an IQ that could only be a single digit, and the money they make is multiples of people I know with ivy league computer science grad degrees. And they work way less, vacation way more, don’t have engineering deadlines that keeps them at the office and away from family. Only way to get smart and charismatic is to read like a mad man and engage people when you’re not reading. More interesting is that, by reading and challenging yourself, you can actually thicken the cerebral cortex - meaning that by pushing yourself, your brain will physically respond, which, perhaps, might be a method to perform better with the discredited and archaic IQ test: Nurturing brain plasticity: impact of environmental enrichment

Effective way: proven! It has been known for some time that our brain is not static but neuroplastic, making new connections all the time, but this would have an effect on the longer term. But since you're talking about IQ, and not necessarily fluid intelligence, so I suggest you want to have better scores, which is possible. I don't know if it can be done with subtests such as short-term memory, processing speed, but certainly linguistic and pattern recognition. How to improve pattern recognition? This is my observation: online IQ tests are far from a concrete measure of your actual cognitive skills. But there are online tests, which provide a concrete objective measurement based on their online sample size (n). This is extremely important to look up for practicing. Because despite they do not give a concrete realistic measurement of your actual mental power, their measuring method is stable, so a higher result is actually a higher result based on their scaling method and not a commercially given result like many tests online. So the point is that absolutely no commercial measurement method must be used, but an objective one based on THEIR sample, representative of reality or not, so that improvement is actually a geometrically analyzed improvement and not a randomly chosen commercial number. This is important because you want to measure progress, despite not improving your G. Okay now that it is clear, now you should never look up answers from the puzzles again, even after taking the test, just don’t do it, never. This is my fact that I observed myself if you take the test once and then immediately again but in half the time without looking up the answers (be super objective and honest with yourself) you will score better on IQ tests with reliable MEASUREMENT METHODS, NOT RESULTS. Really this I have proven myself several times, my explanation is: if you do it first from a lazy state of mind, then you are less effective at recognizing patterns, it's like having to do a warm-up for sports matches, that's why it's going to be the second time better up to 14 points, even if you still didn’t know the answers and it is the same you did 5 minutes earlier. But it is just because you are sharper the second time, and expect more complexity. So do this. But NEVER look up the answers. Also before the actual test the day, do a few tests to get into that state of mind. Test this and tell me if it worked: 2x an objective measurement method, 2nd time in half the time you did before. Did it increase the second time? Manage your expectations: if you have never taken an IQ test, you have lower expectations of the patterns that occur, which will have a negative effect on your time management and on your attitude towards solving the puzzles. Realize that most puzzles go from less complex to more complex, expect this! So for the less complex use intuitive linear reasoning, until it no longer works this way. Then put in what I call: the paranoid mindset: expect more complex patterns, think not only horizontally, but also vertically and also diagonally! Expect all of these. In addition, also expect that within the figures, multiple patterns can occur, up to 3 that are non-linear independent of each other, for example, one phenomenon can go up, the other down, while they slide to the right/left. The other can change color in the next block. Because realize, they do not only appeal to your thinking ability. If you knew the variables you probably had the ability to solve it, most people would have been technical ‘geniuses’, but the test also appeals to critical thinking: sharply concentrated, investigative ability. But if you search with this intention, you will find them better. But, do not apply this method to the intuitive or easy puzzles: time management. All in all, solve as many puzzles as possible, but never look for the answer: be honest with yourself and measure your improvements, which you do not have to share with anyone, it is for yourself. Important to say: this does not increase your natural critical thinking ability or reasoning ability, pattern recognition ability: it simply puts you in a state of mind for being open to the possibilities that may arise, thereby also making you better at solving the pattern puzzles.
