In real terms, IQ scores aren’t very important. IQ tests can be fooled like any other test. They rely on set patterns and question types, by practicing these questions, you’ll be become better at answering them, thus giving you a higher IQ score. In the grand scheme of things I think IQ scores are very misleading. I’ve achieved scores of 135+ before. I’d consider myself to be a little more intelligent average, but nowhere near as intelligent as a score of 135 suggests. I just got good at taking IQ and aptitude tests. If you want to increase your intelligence, I’d focus on improving your memory and honing your thinking processes and approaches. Why memory? There is strong evidence (Tourva et al.), 2016) to suggest that working memory have an enormous influence on the development of a person's fluid intelligence (general intelligence). A high IQ score tends to correlate with a strong working memory. Intelligent people can be poor thinkers and it's theorised that intelligence is strongly related to how many things you can hold in your working memory at once (Bailey H, 2008), not necessarily the processes or mental approaches that those people use. There are a huge number of resources online for improving memory, but from a practical and instantly usable viewpoint, Jonathan Levi’s SuperLearner course and work Anthony Metivier’s magnetic memory methods are your best option. Thinking itself if a made up of a combination of skills and can be improved by following certain processes or thinking exercises. I’d advised looking into lateral / parallel thinking methods as lateral thinkers use information in a different or provocative way and challenge assumptions or accepted concepts. Lateral and parallel thinking that enable such leaps and to identify patterns and causes that no one else can. Additionally a good grasp of situation analysis and strategy will help you to think a step ahead of your peers. Combined with keen observation skills; you'll be able to examine an environment and quickly gather all the relevant information, evidence and opinions. Once you have this information, you can organise it and develop successful and highly relevant strategies.

Intelligence is trainable about in the same amount that VO2-Max is. If you haven’t been intellectually working out much at all in the recent years, you will get noticeable improvement over a 2 month period. You can improve some over the next few months, but then after that gains will be minimal. For the WAIS (Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scales), some subtests are education-dependent, on the premise that intellect determines the capacity for education and rate of learning. So increasing your math skills, vocabulary, and general knowledge can help an IQ score on the WAIS. If you think your education level is nowhere near your intellectual potential, addressing this could improve your IQ score on the WAIS-IV, particularly on the verbal IQ side. Motivation differences alone can boost your IQ score by around 5 points. If your last test session was neutral motivation (not really aware you were being tested), assuming you don’t have test anxiety issues, coming a new test session aware and fully motivated to do well in it can boost your score a bit. Score boost can be even bigger if you had a anti-motivation on the last test session (kids who don’t care and make pictures out of their filled-in answer sheet bubbles during standardized testing are non-motivated) If you are able to benefit from all three of the above, you could get a 10–15 point boost in your IQ result. If you cannot benefit from any above the three (you are in an intellectual occupation, were very motivated the last time you took an IQ test, and you are already well educated) then your IQ will not change much at all, maybe +/- 2. If you want to boost your IQ score and don’t care about its accuracy at all you can buy and practice with an actual Wechsler test kit. There’s plenty of them on eBay: wechsler intelligence scale | eBay . A full WISC-IV or WAIS-III kit will run you $400–600, and are the previous versions, so you won’t get the full benefit of ‘having all the answers to the test’ that an actual psychologist has to cheat their way into high IQ societies (the Glia family of societies do look out for this though). Frequent re-testing with the same IQ test can also cause score inflation because you’ll remember the items you had before.

Read widely. Read across generations, cultures and languages. Read fiction and non-fiction. Read autobigraphies from the Americans who dropped bombs on Japan and the Japanese who survived it. Read popular science books about wormholes, and pseudo-science books about crystals. Read books from Darwin and Dawkins, and books from creationists and zealots. Read Jurassic Park and Game of Thrones, and The Iliad and Beowulf. Read Murakami, Lovecraft, Chaucer, and Hugo.  Learn to solve a rubik's cube in under a minute. Solve a hard sudoku puzzle every day. Play chess against the computer or a competent friend. Solve crossword puzzles, play scrabble, form palindromes and anagagrams. Learn to program. There are a wide variety of programming languages out there, ranging from very simple to brain-exploding. I suggest 'Python'. It is pretty simple but quite powerful. Choose a new field to study. If you are bad at mathematics, change that. Choose between a 'hard' science like physics or chemistry, and 'softer' ones like psychology or sociology. Whatever takes your fancy. Learn a new language. Bilingual people have been shown to have higher intellect on average. Read the news every day and dig deeper. What are the root causes for the problems in the world. What are both sides to the stories? Read right wing and left wing blogs. Who is right? Learn the facts and make up YOUR OWN mind. Do IQ tests. Personally I think boiling intelligence down to a single number is nonsense, but doing practice tests will stretch your intelligence and has the added benefit of making you better at IQ tests. Learn a musical instrument. Increasing digit dexterity increases intelligence. Do sports. Seriously. A healthy body is important for a healthy mind.  Final word. I like to think about this: All areas of study/entertainment are very exciting. Perhaps you are a 'jock' who laughs at nerds playing dungeons and dragons. Perhaps you are a rugged guy who thinks the fashion industry is BS, or a girl who thinks shooty shooty computer games are a waste of time. But if you spent any time actually learning about those mysterious 'other' endeavors, you would grow to appreciate, perhaps even enjoy, them. It's so easy to say 'not my thing' when we have never even looked into them.  So go wild, step out of your comfort zone. You will learn so much.

You need to be one in the first place. A Genius is born not made, it’s in your DNA so to speak. There are certain traits you MUST have naturally in order to think/operate as a Genius. There are fundamental differences in the hemispheric functions within the brain of any individual. The left hemisphere contains all your memories, experiences, education, habits, learned patterns of behavior. Conversely the right hemisphere contains creativity, novelty, chaos, a more real time view of the world and in my view is where the higher intelligence lives. Example there 2 base types of intelligence; First is Crystallized Intelligence and refers to the ability to use knowledge acquired through past learning or experience. This is not much use to you when a new novel/complex problem needs to be solved. The second is Fluid Intelligence refers to the ability to reason and solve problems in unique and novel situations and this is what a Genius has and is very rear. We all possess both types of intelligence, but they don’t operate together simultaneously with one always dominant over the other. It comes down to which one you default to and use most often. Most individuals I’ve observed in my life and I’m now 50+ operate like they are on railways lines/autopilot being very predictable in how they view the world. This is an expression of Crystallized Intelligence at it’s most basic level. The smartest/most intelligent individuals I’ve met express Fluid Intelligence (very few) and are moving targets being mostly unpredictable in positive way. I can count them on one hand! The main problem is how most individuals are in society are over socialized and constantly caring of what other people think of them. What a waste of metal energy. A Genius doesn’t care what you think of them! Here are 2 quotes; 1 “Great minds discuss ideas; average minds discuss events; small minds discuss people” Eleanor Roosevelt. 2. “All greatness of character is dependent on individuality. The man who has no other existence than that which he partakes in common with all around him, will never have any other than an existence of mediocrity” James Fenimore Cooper. As you can see it is very easy to become average through over socialization :)

Before figuring out how to boost something, you need to understand what it is. Intelligence is no different. First, IQs do not test intelligence, they test your intelligence relative to everyone else’s intelligence. An IQ of 100 means exactly average. Tests include questions of logic, comprehension and breadth of knowledge. Tests are also configured to adjust for age. To have a result of 100, an adult must have adult level abilities in logic, comprehension and breadth of knowledge compared with a child requiring child level abilities.
